charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I am trekking 100km across Greenland
story:
﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿On 3rd August 2018, myself and 99 other HSBC colleagues from around the world will  trek 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland. With no access to typical facilities, everyone will be carrying their own personal equipment and camping gear for 5 days, sleeping rough in the middle of nowhere, in order to raise money for WaterAid.

All money raised will go direct to WaterAid and not contribuite to the industrial strength eye mask I will require to be able to sleep in 24 hour day light... But because Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. ﻿﻿﻿

﻿

﻿
title: Danelle's 100km Arctic Adventure

story:
Enduramaxx's heart has always been in water conservation and there is no better cause to support than Water Aid!

On Friday 15th December 2017 the Enduramaxx staff are celebrating Christmas Jumper Day to help raise money for Water Aid #Untapped appeal. What's more, every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.

Our fundraising page will be live until 31st January 2018.

A little bit about Water Aid: Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

Employees from Scottish Water will face their fears by bungee jumping or swinging from a bridge in support of WaterAid Scotland!

In a combination of two activities the Highland Fling Bungee and the Highland Fling Bridge Swing at Killiecrankie a group of brave individuals will be raising money through sponsorship for WaterAid.

If you want to support the fantastic work that WaterAid Scotland does meanwhile sponsoring a friend, colleague or family member to do one of these daring activities then please donate to this page.

eventName: Mikes 75lb Weight Loss Challenge by 19 Dec 2018
pageSummary: I am raising money because it frees children's time so they can be schooled.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My goal this year is to lose 75lbs, so as part of my incentive, I am looking to help 1001 people to a better life.

Clean water on tap will save children from walking miles to collect dirty water.  This will improve their health and give them time for an education, which, over time will help lift them from poverty and inspire them to help others.

If you were to sponsor me 1p per pound weight loss, thats only £7.50.

If you include gift aid, that becomes £9.38 and you will have provided 90 days water. 

 And changed lives forever.  So go on then, you know it makes sense.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Dearest friends and family, please help us collect because Peter truly believed in their cause.
pageSummaryWhat: Dearest friends and family, please help us collect
story:
Dearest friends and family,


We are truly grateful for your love and support during this difficult time. As most of you know, our dear Peter (my Petey, Alex's hero of a dad), was unexpectedly taken from us in the early hours on Saturday 30 December. Peter passed away in his sleep after what was a truly valiant and inspirational effort to recover from his tragic accident back in early October. 

Peter will be forever cherished in our memories and we hope that this small gesture will help us to honour his. Peter was a firm supporter of WaterAid and all of the great work that they continue to do - he truly believed that everyone in the world deserves, as a basic human right, to have access to clean water. 

I hope you will all join us in helping WaterAid to make that happen one day in (what I sincerely hope will be) the not too distant future.

With love and thanks,

Annie
title: In loving memory of Peter Graham Ford
pageSummaryWhy: Peter truly believed in their cause.

pageSummary: I am cycling 2 x 100 mile sportives to raise money because everyone deserves safe water and sanitation
pageSummaryWhat: I am cycling 2 x 100 mile sportives to raise money
story:
I have chosen to support WaterAid as little is more important than having access to safe, clean water and decent sanitation.  WaterAid's work is essential in improving this vital infrastructure for impoverished communities across the globe. These simple measures can prevent disease and enable communities to achieve their potential.

To raise money I am cycling 100 miles at both the Diss 9 town sportive on the 24th June, and the Ride 100 in London/ Surrey on the 29th July (to prove the first one wasn't a fluke).  

I would be very grateful for any donations to this vital cause!

eventName: A year of only drinking water (as a beverage)
pageSummary: A year of only drinking water (as a beverage) because we are so fortunate when others are without
pageSummaryWhat: A year of only drinking water (as a beverage)
story:
I guess growing up with parents who were missionaries in Africa and visiting when I was 12 years old I remember how tiny some of those African children were and how in some places water doesn't just come out a tap like it does for us. We would have to walk to carry water home!

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Let's help bring a smile to those beautiful little faces!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
So..... I had another crazy moment and signed up for the London Marathon and got a place, arghhhhh!! For those of you who don’t know how far a Marathon is, it’s 26.2 miles....

....I say another crazy moment as i’ve done some WaterAid work recently.... cleaned toilets at Glastonbury in Summer 2017...nice I know.... but these are the reasons why I have chosen to support WaterAid.....

844 million people don’t have clean water close to home.

2.3 billion people don't have a decent toilet of their own.

31% of schools don’t have clean water.

Every minute a newborn dies from infection caused by lack of safe water and an unclean environment.

Diarrhoea caused by dirty water and poor toilets kills a child under 5 every 2 minutes.

Around the world up to 443 million school days are lost every year because of water-related illnesses.

The World Bank says promoting good hygiene is one of the most cost effective health interventions.

If everyone, everywhere had clean water, the number of diarrhoeal deaths would be cut by a third. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. 

.....please sponsor me and together we can change lives.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As many of you will now know Elizabeth Meredith lost her short but courageous battle against cancer on the 22nd of January. She was a truly beautiful person inside and out. She was a wonderful wife, mother and grandmother but she was also many things to others aswell sister, daughter, aunt, friend, teacher, member of a choral society, founder of kings kitchen and active member of St Margaret’s church congregation. As a family we are devastated and would request that rather than flowers people would consider a donation to the two charities mum held close to her heart. Tree Aid and Water Aid were two charities that she supported monthly and we would like to make a donation in her name to them. Anything on the just giving page will go to Water Aid and any monetary donations given on the day of the funeral will go to tree Aid.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: We are raising money because every deserves the right to clean water!
story:
On Tuesday 27th February the Severn Trent Trust Fund will be hosting a Jailbreak all with the aim of raising money for WaterAid! The jailbreak will take place at the West Midlands Heritage Police Station who have kindly donated the prison to us for the day so that we can literally lock up our prisoners! 

2 prisoners will be taking part, Tony Ballance, Director of Strategy and Regulation Severn Trent and Chairman of the Severn Trent WaterAid Committee and CEO of Auriga Services Mark Abrams will be locked up for the day with the aim of raising funds for some of the world's poorest communities. 

The Jailbreak is part of the Severn Trent Trust Fund's 20th Anniversary Celebrations which has seen us take part in a series of challenges over the past 12 months with the aim of raising £20,000 to support the vital work WaterAid are doing. 

If you'd like to support our prisoners please make a donation and be part of the cause which helps to set them free and help communities all over the world at the same time. 

WaterAid help the world's poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water. 1 in 10 people don't have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don't have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: We are running the Robin Hood Half Marathon because we want to supply clean water to those in need
pageSummaryWhat: We are running the Robin Hood Half Marathon
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Clean water is essential for life, but one in ten of the World's population do not have access to it. This, and a lack of safe sanitation, result in over two million people dying from water-related diseases every year.

Severn Trent helped to establish WaterAid in 1981 and with your help we would like to raise money for those who aren't as fortunate as us to have safe clean water everyday.

A few of us that work for Severn Trent and therefore with water every day have decided to run the Robin Hood Half Marathon on 30th September 2018 to raise as much money as we can for this special charity.

Lets reach our target!!

Thanks

Team Severn Trent

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Raising £1,500 because Water is a basic human right that everybody needs.
story:
Did you know that every minute, a newborn baby dies from infection caused by unclean water and the environment?

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified and healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their future for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

What am I doing? 
I will be taking part in a mini trekking expedition to 3 of the tallest mountains in the UK to complete the National Three Peak Challenge. Please help me reach the finish line! :) 

Why your donation matters
Every donation is a step closer towards giving more people access to a basic human right – water. It’s worth more than silver and gold, yet it’s so easy to forget how precious water really is to our survival.

A Big THANK YOU!

If you donate, I will be ever so grateful because I know that completing this challenge will be worthwhile, and you will be on this journey with me. 

Feel free to “splash out” generously – pun intended.

Thank you so much for stopping by and for your donation!

Victoria

https://www.wateraid.org/uk/

pageSummary: We are dedicating the Lincoln 150 to Kev Moody because he believed everyone should have clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: We are dedicating the Lincoln 150 to Kev Moody
story:
Kevin Moody (Kev) was a mechanic at Littlecoats WTW in Grimsby and was a well known and popular guy who had an infectious smile and relentless optimism. Unfortunately after a 10-month battle and intensive treatment for a inoperable brain tumour, he passed away in October 2017 aged 52 leaving a wife, family and many friends and colleagues. Those who knew him said he was renowned for his energy and positive attitude for life and his love for cycling was well-known. He completed the Lincoln 150 on more than one occasion, one year completing the journey down to Pitsford on a pristine vintage ‘Viscount’ bike. The WaterAid team have been given permission from his family to rename the Lincoln 150 ride to the ‘Kev Moody 150’ in memory or this much loved and respected colleague. For more information on Kev and his passion for life please visit: https://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/news/grimsby-news/tributes-popular-grimsby-mechanic-who-703204

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I have completed the 100km South Coast Challenge because clean water increases the chance of a healthy life
pageSummaryWhat: I have completed the 100km South Coast Challenge
story:
Thank you for visiting my WaterAid fundraising page! 

Water is fundamental to life and access to it is a basic human right. However, 844 million people globally do not have access to clean water.  Climate change is exacerbating the problem with extreme drought and flooding events particularly effecting poorer communities. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene children are born healthier. They get the chance of a decent education and grow up to become adults.

I have chosen to support Water Aid in order to help give people a chance to take back control of their lives and thrive as communities. Basic but life changing infrastructure doesn't have to be expensive either. £20 pays for a pair of taps and £37 pays for a hand pump to provide clean drinking water.

I am raising money for Water Aid and have completed the 100km (62 miles) South Coast Challenge in a continuous walk from Eastbourne to Arundel along the beautiful South Downs Way. It was a daunting challenge over day and night and I finished in a time of 26 hours 36 minutes and 3 seconds!

Many thanks for your donation and best wishes from me!

pageSummary: On Sept 9th I’ll be running the Great North Run because it was the charity my Dad always supported
pageSummaryWhat: On Sept 9th I’ll be running the Great North Run
story:
On September 9th, Sarah and I will be running the Great North Run in aid of Water Aid.  The event falls on the weekend between the first anniversary of Dad's death and what would have been his 75th birthday, and seeing as the run will take us through the area near to where he grew up, it seems a fitting challenge.  We've chosen Water Aid because Dad used to work for one of the big water companies, and he spent time abroad working on projects in places like Lesotho.  Water Aid was one of the charities he always supported. 
Any contribution you would like to make to the fundraising would be greatly appreciated by us both. Thank you x

pageSummary: We're building a recycled bottle River Thames because we want to give others a fair chance in life.
pageSummaryWhat: We're building a recycled bottle River Thames
story: This is Wyvil Primary School's third, annual fundraiser for WaterAid: it is an important part of our curriculum to make children aware of global inequalities and to involve our whole community in working to bring about change.  This year we are building a plastic bottle model of the River Thames to display on our railings.  Having set ourselves the ambitious target of £2000, we will mark our success on the way by highlighting the bridges and monuments we reach.  We hope that you will kindly support us.

pageSummary: I'll be "conquering" Greenland(or be conquered by) because simply we all need water to survive!
pageSummaryWhat: I'll be "conquering" Greenland(or be conquered by)
story:
I am once again asking for your sponsorships for my upcoming
Arctic Challenge – a 5-day trekking in remote Greenland this August, with all
donations benefiting the WaterAid Programme! 
As some of you may recall, back in 2014, Anson and I challenged
ourselves with taking on the Inca Trail in Peru which was one of our most
memorable experiences.

This time, I’m going without my personal porter, covering
100 kms and spending four nights in a tent in one of the most remote parts on
earth….places that I will set foot on (and probably can never pronounce the
names) include Lake Tasersuaq, Iluliumanersuup Portornga and Innajuattoq.

Please open up your wallets (wide) and support such good cause.  All donations go to the WaterAid Programme.   With the recent water rationing in Cap Town -S Africa, we are reminded that this can happen to any metropolitan areas  where we've always taken for granted clean water from the tap for drinking, cooking and hygiene.   And let's not forget, we need water for the vineyards which give us our beloved wine:)

Mia has decided to complete a marathon in a month, I'm sure Lily will do some miles too and of course me and Andrew will be along side her. eventName: Sing for Water at Totally Thames
pageSummary: Singing at Sing For Water 2018 because clean water saves lives
story:
Caterham Community Choir are again supporting Sing for Water this year.  Members are learning a special repertoire of songs which will be performed at 
 Sing for Water London
Sunday 16th September 2018, 2.15pm
The Scoop, More London, Queens Walk, SE1 2DB
All welcome to come and enjoy a wonderful, riverside spectacle as choirs from across the country come together to raise their voices for WaterAid's life-saving projects in Rwanda.  

It only costs £15 to give one person access to clean water for life so every note sung and penny raised makes a difference.

More info at 
http://totallythames.org/event/sing-for-water
https://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/events/sing-for-water-london

About Sing for Water
Sing for Water was initiated by composer Helen Chadwick as a project to raise money for WaterAid at The Thames Festival in 2002. Mass choral events now take place across the country and have raised over £1 million for WaterAid's life-saving projects providing clean water, hygiene and sanitation in the world's poorest communities. 

About WaterAid
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
Some of the crazy folks in Southern Waters Procurement team have decided to support WaterAid by running the 10k Bogstacle on 27th October.

**TO ALL SPONSORS - By donating you get to vote on the difficulty of the obstacles we have to do on event day! Please cast your vote in the donation comments box by including either:#BOGBUDDY - if you want to be nice and let us do the easier obstacles #BOGBADDY - if you want to set us a real challenge and have us do the harder obstacles.Whichever one gets most votes (regardless of donation amount) is the one we'll be doing. You decide!

**BOGSTACLE is setup and run by the international charity WaterAid to raise funds and awareness for our vital work to help make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation.

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Woofy and Sulli's Yorkshire 3 peaks Challenge
pageSummary: Walking the 24 miles of the Yorkshire 3 peaks because having easy access to clean water is a human right
pageSummaryWhat: Walking the 24 miles of the Yorkshire 3 peaks
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Upon reading an article about a Zambian woman carrying 20 litres of water nearly 4 miles (everyday), we propose to carry two 20 litre bottles (over 20kg) of water over the distance of over 24 miles and climbing over 3 of Yorkshires highest peaks which is over 5200ft of ascent. 

With an estimated time of around 10 hrs to walk it and considerable weight in our backpacks, we hope to raise awareness and some cash for a very important world cause.

Your sponsorship is most grateful. 

Thank you

Woofy and Sully

story:
60miles (almost 100km...) cycling, 10miles hiking, 12miles canoeing in one and a half day... fair to say that it is going to be challenging. Never done something like that before nor I am fit enough to do it... but it's for a great cause so it's definitely worth the effort and the pain that will follow... We take many things for granted but people in other parts of the world do not even have access to clean water. Please help us to raise as much possible to support WaterAid in their great mission!

story:

For the first leg of our journey, from Scotland to Senegal we are raising money for wateraid and really hope you can help support this amazing cause which is helping communities across the globe.

Follow our story at kindnessofstrangers.blog

story:
I don't think that having access to clean drinking water and toilets should be a luxury for anybody but that's the situation for 10% of the world's population. WaterAid are working to change that within a generation.

The Great North Run is only a half-marathon but for someone like me who has not run more than 6 miles in my long life it's a big challenge. I hope that you can support me and WaterAid with a small donation.

pageSummary: Jane and myself are running the Great North Run because We want to support this brilliant charity
pageSummaryWhat: Jane and myself are running the Great North Run
story:
Last year, my school friend Jane and myself ran the Great North Run for the first time. If we could go back in time to our teenage selves, I’m not sure we would have believed  that it was possible. It was such a wonderful and inspiring experience. That great hub of people all heading towards South Shields, all with their own reasons for doing it. It was very humbling, and wonderful to be a tiny part of such a big event. We felt proud of our region, and very happy to be part of it. People tell you how the local support along the route is unwavering, but it really is, it’s marvellous. 

This year we are very proud to be raising money for Water Aid. This is why. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
Emily, Lucy and Ian are joining the AW Rutland fun ride on 22nd September,  a 17 mile circular route around Rutland Water.  Lizzie is taking part in the 'Rutland 125' from Rutland Water to Pitsford Water and back over 2 days. 

We are lucky enough to have clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene and these should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Please support us in making lives better for so many people.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: running a HALF MARATHON(!!!) because they aim to provide clean water for all!
story:
Hi everyone

I'm running a half marathon.. yes running..yes 13.1 miles..yes me..for WaterAid. 

I'm hoping you can all dig as deep as possible - matched funding means the first £1,500 raised will be matched completely. That means if you donate £20, you are effectively donating £40!

Thanks as always all - please work your magic!

Some high level figures - 

750m (10%) of the world's population don't have safe water to drink

33% of the world's population don't have use of a decent toilet - that's 2.5 billion people

500,000 The number of children who die each year from diseases resulting from unsafe water or bad sanitation

23m people reached with safe water since WaterAid was founded in 1981

£84m The charity's income in 2014/15, up from £27m in 2005

2030 The year when WaterAid aims to ensure that everyone in the world has safe water, sanitation and hygiene



Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

pageSummaryWhat: Running an obstacle course with a 'damaged' leg
story:
I signed up to Bogstacle and days later I tore my right meniscus in the run-up. It was terrible and had to miss playing football everyday.

I wasn't going to run it but I signed up and said I was going to do it so here we are, I'll be hopping around the majority of the course while my team carry me over obstacles because that is what happens when you sign up to ensure everyone has access to clean water and good hygiene.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

pageSummary: I'm running the 2019 London Marathon because I got a place in the ballot so 100% goes to them
story:
Surprisingly I got a place in the ballot for this year and decided to again raise some money for WaterAid.  Those who know me know I have run many marathons, but to be fair not in the last couple of years and I will be putting in many hours over the next few months as I intend to at last beat the elusive, for me, 3 hour 30 mark.  To know I'm being supported through those dark winter months would be great but even greater is knowing a few more people round the world will have access to fresh water and sanitation.  We know the problems associated with providing these services in this country which is both rich in water resources and finances to provide them.  In many countries it is beyond the capabilities of governments to provide these services for many reasons, but by working with one community at a time we can make the difference between a community suffering from sickness, poverty and disillusionment, to a healthy, positive and financially stable one, and that's got to be worth a few quid out of anyones pocket regardless of my efforts running round London.

Really hope you can all help.

Leo

Here's a note from WaterAid themselves:

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.  With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

eventName: Sing for Water London at Totally Thames 2019
pageSummary: Singing and fundraising because they provide clean water & sanitation
story:
Sing for Water Pop Up Project - Summer Rehearsals
Founded by Xenia Davis of Making Music, this project aimed and successfully increased the attendance of younger singers at Sing for Water in 2016.  For two years running the Pop Ups have been located at WaterAid offices and have been a wonderful way for singers to meet, sing and fundraise together.

Dates – Tuesday evenings from 6.30-8.30pm July 23rd, August 6th & 20th, September 3rd  

Booking is essential via Eventbrite - https://sfwpopupproject2019.eventbrite.co.uk

Venue – WaterAid Offices, 47-49 Durham St, London SE11 5JD

Contribution – suggested £5 donation to WaterAid – either in cash on the day or via this page

Fundraising - Each singer is required to raise a minimum of £50 each in sponsorship to take part in Sing for Water. This fundraising is separate to any donation made for these rehearsals. All funds raised help bring lifesaving water to people in need. If people drop out this impacts on our fundraising so please let us know if for any reason you cannot make it so we can fill your place. There are many ways to make fundraising fun - for more info, ideas, and tips on the WaterAid website - http://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/start-fundraising

About Sing For Water London
Sing for Water was initiated by Helen Chadwick and the Thames Festival Trust to raise money for WaterAid in 2002. Now in it’s 16th Year, the combined efforts of nationwide events have now raised over  £1 million for WaterAid’s lifesaving projects. This year, Sing for Water London at the Thames Festival will take place on 
Sunday 15th September at 2.15pm at The Scoop, City Hall, Queen's Walk, London SE1 2AA
Choirs from across the country join together to sing watery themed songs to raise funds for WaterAid's lifesaving projects.

About WaterAid
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

pageSummary: Running and Laughing to beat Breast Cancer because Clean water saves lives! Please give if you can
pageSummaryWhat: Running and Laughing to beat Breast Cancer
story:
It would be lovely if you felt able to sponsor me. But whether or not you do, ladies please please please check your breasts every month. And gentlemen – check your testicles. Or check each other….

My breast cancer journey began on the 3rdJuly 2018 when I brushed my hand against my breast in the bath, and found a lump. 10 days earlier I had run the Swansea Half-Marathon and thought of myself as a fit and healthy 50-year-old.

Since then I have been recording my “Adventures with Breast Cancer” on Facebook, where only the fun bits make it through. We are encouraged to get angry with cancer, but I think laughing at it is more effective. And much better for mental health.

My Surgery and Chemotherapy have been complicated by several episodes of infection and hospital admissions, which have made a serious dent in my fitness. The Chemotherapy will continue into the New Year, and then I will have 6 weeks of Radiotherapy.

Regular exercise is known to aid breast cancer recovery and survival both during treatment and beyond. Therefore I am forcing my depleted muscles to the gym and round the park.

My long-term goal is the Cardiff Half-Marathon in October 2019. It will be my 8th Half-Marathon, but I hope not my slowest…… 

Currently I am struggling to run for more than 10 minutes, so my first goal is the Newport Christmas parkrun (5k) on 22nd December. I am very fortunate to have lots of lovely supporters running with me that day. You are very welcome to join us, see here: https://www.facebook.com/events/585843425205827/

If you would like to sponsor my “Journey to the Cardiff Half” then you will be supporting Wateraid, a charity that saves lives by providing clean water and hygienic toilets wherever they are needed. If you have 2 minutes there is a lovely short film on their website which shows how clean water not only saves lives but improves its quality in so many ways: https://www.wateraid.org/uk/

You may wonder why I am choosing to support Wateraid rather than a breast cancer charity. The answer is this: I am unlucky to have breast cancer, but very lucky to have been born in the UK, where I am receiving and will continue to receive excellent treatment, and as a result will probably live long enough to become demented and incontinent.

Meanwhile, worldwide, every 2 minutes a mother loses a child under 5 as a result of illness caused by dirty water. That is 720 grieving women every day. More than a million dead children every 4 years. Yet we know how to prevent this grief and loss of life, and compared to cancer research, it is very cheap to do.

Women in the Developing World also have high rates of breast cancer; once these ladies cite breast cancer research as their top priority, then it will become mine too.

Thanks for reading.

PS Check your breasts! Now! Wherever you are…. If anyone looks at you strangely, tell them what you’re doing and suggest they do the same

pageSummary: NA
story:
We are mostly a group of scientists based in London. Much of our research is focused on water (and ice). In particular, we are working towards molecular-level understanding of water and in gaining insights to help develop innovative solutions to some of the world's water problems. 

WaterAid is an international charity working to provide clean water and decent toilets to everyone, everywhere. Since we believe that clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life, we're taking part in this year's Hever triathlon in aid of WaterAid.

This is our second year at Hever and after last year's shock victory in the half-ironman relay we're entering two teams this time round. Last year's victorious team of Phil, Gabriele, and Angelos will compete again in the half-ironman. Also competing, over the Olympic distance, is "Team Zen", which includes husband and wife (Andrea and Sara) plus Patrick. 

We've been training hard (some more so than others!) for our swim, bike, run effort x 2. Please offer us whatever support you can because it's going to a great cause...

For more information on our research see: www.chem.ucl.ac.uk/ice &  https://www.sossogroup.uk

I'm running the Virgin London Marathon in 2011 (please ignore the event category on this page - I was originally due to run the 2010 race but an injury prompted me to defer. I wanted to keep this page going seeing as I'd already received sponsorship - but there's no way of amending the selected event) and am hoping to raise some money for WaterAid. Any sponsorship would be very welcome and much appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks,

Al.

story:
We are once again holding our very own Great Thames Bake off and cake sale on Friday 14 February.

Anyone can take part, all you need to do is bake a cake at home and bring it in to sell. We are also asking everyone to dress down, wearing pink and/or red for Valentine’s Day and donate lovingly.

Bakers can bring in their culinary creations to sell and be in with a chance of being crowned Thames Star Baker. All you need to do is send in a picture of you and your creations to T4Beventsteam@thameswater.co.uk. The star bakers will have their photos published in the Source. From this we’ll judge the cake that looks the most lovingly made!

Bakers can either sell cakes within their teams, or try and to get your whole floor or department involved. Why not have your own taste testing competition and let us know who wins?

All money raised through the sale with go towards our Thames4Bangladesh programme and will change the lives of some of the poorest communities living in four small towns in Bangladesh. 

Happy baking!

eventName: 'Living below the line' and 'UNICEF Tap Project' for a week
pageSummary: going to take part in two challenges because I want to provide clean water and sanitation.
pageSummaryWhat: going to take part in two challenges
story:
From 19.02.2014 00:00 until 24.02.2014 00:00 I will be undertaking the ‘Live Below the Line’ and the ‘UNICEF Tap Project’.

The ‘Live Below The Line’ challenge is when you live off £1 a day. This means that you have no money for luxuries and that you have to wisely spend your budget on food. The aim of undertaking this challenge to change the way that people in the UK think about poverty.

https://www.livebelowtheline.com/uk

The ‘UNICEF Tap Project’ is simple. You put down your phone and provide people with clean water. There is 768 million people in the world without clean water. Help reduce that.

http://tap.unicefusa.org/

More on why I’m doing this…

In June this year I embarked on a Raleigh ICS expedition to Mgongo Village in Tanzania, Africa for 10 weeks to address issues relating to water and sanitation. Our team of 6 international volunteers, 5 in-country volunteers and our 2 team leaders started by conducting action research in several sub-villages in the surrounding area. We surveyed houses and schools, and gathered information regarding health and sanitation in their daily lives, looking into how they collect and use water, what diseases they get regularly and much more. We analysed all the data in order to gain greater understanding as to what the key issues were and based our later campaigns on the results.

 

In our later campaigns:

We helped in the construction of latrines in a primary school.

We provided schools with hand washing devices and workshops on hand hygiene.

We taught communities and schools about HIV/AIDS and how to prevent them.

We started up a community women’s group.

 

Even though me and my group accomplished so much, there is much more that we didn’t get to accomplish. We were overwhelmed by issues and that’s in one small village in the whole wide world.

That’s why I’m still trying.

 

https://www.raleighinternational.org/

________________________________________________________

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: You Hungary? Max and Sam's Jailbreak Adventure
pageSummary: NA
story:
YES! Jailbreak is happening! 

Firstly, thank you so much for visiting our page! 

Sam and I have decided to take a risk and not play hockey on a Saturday for once and instead raise some money for a great cause whilst trying to have a bit of fun at the same time. 

Jailbreak is an event that occurs in Universities all over Britain, where students aim to get as far away from the Uni (square) as possible in 48 hours without using any money. Apart from buying food. And water... 

This year, UEA is raising money for WaterAid. An International Charity, WaterAid's goal is to transform lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation. WaterAid aided almost an extra 200,000 people in 2012-2013 from the previous year, reaching roughly 1.7million with clean water. From studying International Development, I know WaterAid attempts to use low-cost, sustainable and community-led initiatives, as well as connecting with governments in an attempt to help them pursue national-level programmes. 

Both Sam and I would be hugely greatful if you could donate any money towards our target, no matter how small you may think it is. If we reach our target, I am sure Sam and I will think of some interesting photos and challenges to do on the way. 

Thank you so much for taking time to donate and read this. 

Options of Travel: 

1. Get to Hungary! 

2. Get to the Shetland Isles

3. Get to Paris via blagging it at the Eurostar 

4. Travel to Belgium to get some chocolate

5. Ipswich?
title: Hungary Yet? Max and Sam's Jailbreak Adventure

pageSummary: turning 40 because I can't be arsed to do exercise for charity.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm 40 this year, and am sick of receiving mugs, aftershave, socks, and other shit for birthdays / Xmas. As such, if you normally give me a present, why not donate to my chosen charity, WaterAid instead? At first glance it may just appear to be a new name for sparkling water, like lemonade or orangeade, but I think there's more to it than that. I can't be arsed explaining it, so see the link instead. I've tried adding proper links to this page twice but given up, it's total wank. 

Obviously, I do loads of stuff for charity, but I just don't like talking about it. This is all a bit embarrassing for me, perhaps publicising what a charitable legend I really am. I'm sorry this has become public knowledge, but it saves one person receiving an unwanted present for their birthday (ie me), it's worth every penny.

Thanks for listening (and hopefully donating)

Simon

pageSummary: doing a Army Assault Course for Water Aid because everybody, everywhere deserves clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: doing a Army Assault Course for Water Aid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Only £16.00 will provide clean water for 1 person  for a whole year.

During the month of April, Brothers Hair Salons work along with the Aveda network to raise funds for WaterAid. Last year together we raised over £170,000 in the UK + Ireland and we plan to beat that this year. In the developing world dirty water, poor sanitation and hygiene spread water related diseases that can be fatal. For 2014 our fundraising will be supporting WaterAid projects in Andhra Pradesh state in India where extreme poverty is widespread and millions of people lack access to clean safe water. Children in particular are usual tasked with collecting water in heavy containers and carrying them for hours at a time.

Just think how many times in a day you use clean water. Can you imagine life without it ?

So please dig deep and donate now

eventName: EPIC Ups and Downs 30 mile Bike Challenge
pageSummary: doing something GREAT for the earth in April because we NEED to do the right thing.
pageSummaryWhat: doing something GREAT for the earth in April
story:
Please support me and WaterAid by donating £5, £10, £20 or more to continue to help.

- 425 community projects to fight toxic pollution
- 520 projects helping communities to advocate for safe and affordable drinking water
- 770 watersheds, such as lakes, wetlands, and rivers, protected
- 1,070 communities addressing climate change, which contributes to water shortages and scarcity across the globe.
- 22,725 women engaged in working towards clean water for their communities
- 57,850 people benefitting from wells and water infrastructure
- 75,250 acres devoted to sustainable agriculture
- 660,000 lives impacted by water related projects

Around 700,000 children die every year from diseases caused by unsafe water and sanitation. Thats almost 2000 children a day. What we take for granted.. help others to have a quality of life, and SAVE lives of millions.
THANK YOU for helping.
Love Gina

pageSummary: NA
story:
Every year, Aveda raises money for WaterAid during Earth Month.

Join us for Earth Month 2014 where our focus will be on providing access to clean, safe water for children and poor communities around the world.  In the developing world, dirty water, poor sanitation and hygeine spread water-related diseases that can be fatal.  Millions of children miss out on school, and families are kept trapped in poverty by not being able to work due to disease and spending hours each day collecting water.  Children often suffer the most from a lack of clean, safe water so they are our focus for Aveda Earth month this year.

Please help in any way that you can, as every penny counts.  We will be doing a number of events, so keep your eyes peeled!!

pageSummary: drinking water only for 2 weeks because everyone should have access to clean, safe water
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm ditching my favourite things for 2 weeks, from Saturday May 3rd.... no coffee, no beer, no wine, nope not even a brew. My challenge is only to drink tap water for 2 weeks to raise money for Wateraid. Imagine having to drink water that could make you ill, or having to walk miles to get it? That's rubbish! Lets change that for someone!

Sounds easy? Well, we'll see, not sure starting the day with no caffeine will be a doddle. Weekends without beer? Boo! But all for a good cause so wish me luck and donate what you can through Justgiving. Even 50p would be amazing! Better still, join me!

Thank you

Jules

pageSummary: I'm Swimming the length of the channel in 4 weeks because I want to make a difference
pageSummaryWhat: I'm Swimming the length of the channel in 4 weeks
story:
my challenge ends on Sunday I'm finding it soo difficult with these cold evenings please show ur support

text CLSM77 £2 or £5 to 70070 to support swimming challenge

to support my charity swim challenge please donate I only have a few days left to complete it

I almost drowned last night body just dosnt want to do it anymore :) #challenge

so after 3 days off to relax my muscles in caught up with 80 lengths tonight feeling good again :)

I'm raising money for #wateraid follow #myjourney

I'm raising money for #wateraid follow #myjourney

I pushed it and done 60 tonight 22 percent of the 22 mile challenge completed so far I'm sooooo hungry

It's that time again.this is the hardest thing I have ever done please show ur support by donating to my page

made an elderly friend in the pool tonight I think he was just shocked I was there and not down the pub on a fri night!!

bit of a rush tonight didn't get in till 7 quick munch and back out the door in 15 minutes #nonstop #madness

50 more done! tonight was hard, pool was busy and I got hit about 3 times and choked on the water a fair few. same again tomorrow :)

another 50 done and dusted now a walk home in the dark and cold. shattered but smiling :)

I now have 50 lengths less to do, :) productive Sunday. Same again tomorrow!!

text CLSM77  £2, £3 or £5 TO 70070 22 miles - 35405 metres - 1416 lengths of the pool - 4weeks

first swim of many tomorrow the challenge is finally here :)

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am part of a small business team that has been given the task to raise £750 as an individual target.

'748 million people – roughly one in ten of the world's population – have no choice but to get water from wherever they can, whether it's a dirty pond or an expensive water vendor.'

'Without access to safe water for drinking, cooking and cleaning, people are more likely to suffer from water-related diseases. These can be fatal, killing over 1,400 children a day.'

My challenge is to swim 22 miles in 4 weeks by attending my local pool 5 times a week to complete 71 lengths (of a 25m pool) each time.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Raising buckets of money because not everyone can enjoy a fresh bucket of water!
story:
Welcome to The Guilty Bucket

Are you guilty of tipping fresh tap water on your head for a recent online challenge?

You have done an amazing thing for charity!

You *did* donate to charity too, right?

While it takes some guts to get brrrr cold under a bucket of water, we are lucky enough to have fresh drinking water on tap! so much of it we take it for granted, and sometimes do crazy things like tip it all over our head without sparing a thought for those who desperately need  fresh water.

Every 15 seconds a child dies from water related diseases, that's about 4 children in the time it took to fill your bucket with fresh water.

#TheGuiltyBucket is here to raise awareness of those who would love a fresh bucket of water. We are not suggesting you stop using fresh water, but simply spare a thought for those who don't have the same luxury.

We are a group of individuals in the UK who believe that everyone should have access to fresh water. Give a fresh bucket of water to someone who needs it for survival.

Now that would be something amazing to share!

Please give generously!

  • £12 buys two taps for a water point
  • £25 buys tools to dig a well
  • £50 buys a handpump!

(This campaign is not endorsed by WaterAid, they are our chosen Water charity, your donations go directly to WaterAid.)

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I am growing my hair and am seeking sponsorship because it addresses the most basic of human rights !
pageSummaryWhat: I am growing my hair and am seeking sponsorship
story:
I have been with WaterAid for nearly 10 years, having joined this wonderful organisation on January 1, 2005. To mark my decade with WaterAid, I have decided to grow my hair for the next four months, till the end of 2014.

Working with WaterAid has been such a fantastic experience. The clear focus that we have - on supporting people gain access to water, sanitation and hygiene in some of the least developed countries of the world and in some of the poorest communities within, is so fundamental to ensuring that people lead healthy, productive and dignified lives. 

In my role, I get to see the work of our local partners and our staff in some difficult, challenging situations. And I always come back inspired by the courage I see in the local communities to be resilient, face these challenges, be part of a change and even lead the change. 

The transformation that I see in people's lives is truly amazing ! So many lives have been saved, so many hours of burden eliminated, so much of dignity restored - just because they have gained access to water, sanitation and hygiene! I feel truly privileged to have played a small role in those far reaching changes and have always been hugely overwhelmed with the amazing support we have received from individuals and organisations.

This challenge of mine is, in a small way, to help us go that bit further and enable us to reach out to some more people. Please sponsor me !

pageSummary: I RAN the Verona Marathon on 05/10/2014 because water is vital to life & Kev's life was water!
pageSummaryWhat: I RAN the Verona Marathon on 05/10/2014
story:
Thank you for donating to such a worthy cause. WaterAid was Kevin's favourite charity and together we have raised nearly £2,000 and made those 42.2 km less painful....and yes it was painful!! 25 degree heat did not help!

Congratulations on helping to continue Uncle Kev's tireless efforts to bring the very necessities of life to all.

From the plains of Africa, and the heat of India, to the chill of North America, and many European countries in between, Kevin's work as a hydrologist also became his personal mission - to improve the quality of life for as many people as he possibly could.  By using his skills as an engineer in order to bring water to them, Kevin changed the lives of many for the better.

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: a day in the life of a toilet
pageSummary: On Wednesday we're dressing as toilets ALL DAY! because we believe everyone should have access to a toilet
pageSummaryWhat: On Wednesday we're dressing as toilets ALL DAY!
story:
On Wednesday it's World Toilet Day and we will be dressing as toilets ALL DAY. On the tube, the walk to work, around the office, in meetings, in the shop buying lunch, in the evening when we are going out dancing, right up until bedtime. It's going to be PRETTY EMBARRASSING, so we'd really appreciate you making it worth the effort by making a donation.

Why on earth are we doing this? Because one in three people in the world do not have access to a safe, private toilet. This is totally unacceptable and means facing disease, harassment and even attacks every time you need to use the loo. Imagine being on your period and having no toilet. It's unbearable to think about.

We can do something to change this - WaterAid is bringing sanitation to communities all over the world! Please make a donation to our page today and help us make sure everyone everywhere has a safe place to go to the toilet, something it is easy to take for granted.

Thanks for your support!
Emma, Lauren, Rachel, Anna, Rebecca, Marco, Hannah, Katy and Connie

eventName: my retirement from Social Care in Staffordshire after over 31 years service and working with so many great people to change the lives of others in a positive way.
pageSummary: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I joined Staffordshire County Council Social Services Department on 6th June 1983 and in that time have worked with many wonderful people who have inspired me so that, in turn, I too can inspire others to live their lives a little easier day by day.

Instead of leaving presents - if you are feeling generous - I would like you to make a contribution towards 'Water Aid', a charity close to my heart, who give many people around the world the chance of introducing clean fresh water into their lives - something the majority of us probably take for granted. We use it daily to clean ourselves, make a drink, wash our cars, use the toilet and much more.      

Last year, the UN officially created a day to recognise the importance of sanitation: World Toilet Day and today, 19th November 2014, is the first such day put aside to recognise it - see http://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/world-toilet-day-2014  for more information.

Having been flushed with success over many years I ask that you too can find somewhere in your heart and something in your pocket to help others around the world in recognition of my work across the county.

Thank you,  John.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My names Tashi, im 25 and have always felt for those that cant drink clean water like we do. I've since then been trying to find ways to raise money for this cause, so I thought why don't we start the hash tag trend again but this time obviously using the #wateraidtashi. But this time I want photos of #wateraidtashi either on a sign, your face, a random place, or somewhere that means something to you. But you have to donate before you have done this. Then upload the photo/video etc.

Simple right?

Lets get this trending!!! We can all do good, even if its only a pound it will do so much more than you think!

Just tag yourself on your photo on my facebook and #wateraidtashi.

I will start so lets see how many of you follow..

eventName: Kate and Aidan Drink only Water in January 2015
pageSummary: We are drinking only water in January 2015 because one in ten people are living without safe water
pageSummaryWhat: We are drinking only water in January 2015
story:
In just a few days, we’ll be raising a glass to the New Year!

And while we can't wait to celebrate, we know that after countless cups of tea and the odd tipple too many, January is the best time to ring in the changes with a healthier lifestyle!        

That's why we'll only be drinking water for the whole month of January 

And here's why it's more than just a detox... 

Safe water is a human right, yet one in ten people are living without it - which can mean illness and even death. This January, let’s change things. 

Thanks :)
Kate and Aidan

pageSummary: I am drinking only tap water for all of January because many people don't have safe, clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: I am drinking only tap water for all of January
story: What's wrong with being drunk?  Well, just ask a glass of water.  Many people will have heard this line from Douglas Adams' most famous work.  But even more do not have access to safe, clean drinking water.  Every day, over 1400 children die from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation.  To raise awareness of this, I have decided to drink only tap water over the next month, eschewing tea and all other beverages.  Please follow my efforts, and donate generously to this important and worthwhile cause.

pageSummary: I want to build a well in Africa. because children are dying from drinking dirty water.
pageSummaryWhat: I want to build a well in Africa.
story:
Hello!

It was my idea to make a well and I am called Madeleine and my age is 5. I came up with this plan when I was watching TV and I saw an advert about poor people in Africa and they didn't have clean water. So I decided to make a well.

I like writing stories so I wanted to share some of them with you. Can you help me by reading my stories and when you read them give some money which will be used to build a well in Africa. You can listen to me reading two of my stories by clicking on the pictures below. Please Help Me! xxx

The Calm Dog

Once upon a time there was a mouse called Wisk. One day Oop came round. Hello he said " I'm off to explore the world". "I'm off too" she said. " "Only an explorer mouse can go out on this dangerous world" he said. "I'm clever" whispered Wisk. She didn't want to upset him but she had to go too.

She followed him to a creepy house. Oop climbed through an open window. Wisk climbed through another open window. "How did you get here?" he said. "I followed you" said Wisk proudly. Oop calmed down. If you are here now and I can't take you back then you need to do what I say. "Brilliant!" cried Wisk.

"Hey you waked up the dog" said Oop. "Run!" said Oop, but Wisk did not run. "Hello I'm Wisk, what's your name?". Wisk picked up a bone. "Woof!" said the dog. Then the owner came in. "Shooo!" cried the owner. " Come on my back" barked the dog. Wisk jumped onto the dogs back. The dog barked as loudly as it could.   Wisk fell off the dogs back. The owner walked downstairs and Wisk became famous and she was in newspapers and in pictures.

The End.

Sleepy Magic

Magic will come into this little head. Relax, relax and sleep. Dream of heaven, how lovely it would be. Tuck tight and be cosy in your little bed. Sleepy tightly, windows closed. In your head you dream of fairies, knights, horses or princesses. Dream of nice things that don't make your head cry.

Grumpy Head

Once upon a time there was a  boy, a grumpy boy. He was grumpy about everything. Mum turned on the light "Its too bright" complained Harry. Harry was his name. Harry got on his horse called Weddy. Weddy rode round the toy shop. "You are going too slow" complained Harry. Weddy stopped at a line of people. As soon as people saw Harry they started looking grumpy like Harry. Then Harry's horse looked grumpy. But then everyone looked grumpy.

Harry climbed onto Weddy. She rode back home. "Dad I've got a problem he cried. Dad ran down the stairs. "Everyone's grumpy!" said Harry. "Just be a bit happier said Dad". "What do you mean?" said Harry. "Just try it" said Dad.

Harry climbed onto Weddy and rode off with a smile on his face. Everyone started looking happy. Harry was happy too.

The end.

A Rich Man or Just a Man

I was in bed. I did see a man. Was he rich or was he poor? But I went back to sleep so I could dream some more. The first thing I dreamed of was if that man was rich or poor... but then mum opened the door. I was still tired so I laid down in bed. But then I saw another man. Was he rich or was he poor? I called "are you rich or poor?" The man answered back, "yes I am rich, but I'm not just a man, I'm a king. No dirt for me!"

I rushed down to meet him. "My name is Whim" said the king. But mum just grabbed me before I could talk. "Hey don't you ever go out of that house to go and play" said mum. "Ok!" I said. So I waved goodbye.

The end.

pageSummary: I am climbing Snowdon on the 20th April because Aveda is fundraising for Earth Month
pageSummaryWhat: I am climbing Snowdon on the 20th April
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

WaterAid is an international non-profit organisation that was set up in 1981 that works in partnership with local organisations in 27 countries in Africa, Asia, Central America and the Pacific region to help poor communities establish sustainable water supplies and latrines and to promote safe hygiene practices. Currently 748 million people in the world don't have access to safe water. The water and sanitation crisis is the second biggest killer of children under five years old worldwide. Aveda’s annual Earth Month campaign unites its global network and has raised over $26 million for environmental causes to date, including £507,000 for WaterAid since Aveda in the UK started supporting WaterAid in 2010.

Snowdon is at an elevation of 1,085 metres (3,560 ft) above sea level, and is the highest point in the British Isles outside the Scottish Highlands.

 Please sponsor me to climb Snowdon and help transform lives.

eventName: Robin James Poole's Boot Camp Challenge
pageSummary: The Rj Team, Poole supporting Aveda's Earth Month! because we want to raise funds for access to clean water.
pageSummaryWhat: The Rj Team, Poole supporting Aveda's Earth Month!
story:
The Robin James Team in Poole are hoping that you will show your gratitude and generosity for taking something that we here all take for granted clean, safe running water.  We think that access to clean water, safe sanitation and hygiene education is something that should be a thing of the past and not an issue that still unfortunately exists today.  We will be working with Aveda's Earth Month to help raise as much money as we can for a project in Andhra Pradesh in India.  We will be doing this by doing a sponsored boot camp challenge on the 28th April so would appreciate any donation large or small to this great cause.  We will also be selling Earth Month Candles and doing hand scrubs and massages for donations.  So don't forget to pop in to the salon for a pamper in exchange for a small donation.

pageSummary: Up @ the o2 because Children need clean water!!!
story:
Dear friends and family.....

As you may or may not know every year i raise money with my company Aveda for water Aid.

This year will be my 5th year and wow have i learnt more in my new role...

Girls as young as 10 have to hair their womb removed (to prevent their monthly cycle)  due to no sanitation and clean water to prevent infections.

Children walk as far as 10 miles for their parents to collect water for the home. This destroys a family life and home.

Last year Aveda raised money to provide new toilets, schools, sanitation, education and this we are powering on to do the same.

Please support me with one of my fears of heights in climbing the O2!!! (god help me) and help me reach my target of £200.

Thank you 

Natasha x

pageSummary: Football penalty shoot out because I am passionate about football
story:
As part of my Bar Mitzvah preparations, I have been learning about Judaism and the importance of being part of a community and supporting charities and doing charitable work, as giving and raising money is part of becoming more involved in the community at large. 
I have chosen Water Aid because there are millions of people across the world who do not have access to clean and fresh water. As a result, many people die from parasites and diseases. I believe that in the 21st century, we all have a right to such a basic human need, that here in the developed world we take for granted.
As I am passionate about football, I have decided to hold a penalty shoot out fundraiser. 
I would appreciate it if you could help me to raise money for my charity. I will be making an additional contribution for each set of goals I let in!

eventName: Leat Feast to raise money for Water Aid and celebrate Drake's efforts
pageSummary: An historic feast to raise funds for Water Aid because in 1590 Francis Drake brought water to Plymouth
pageSummaryWhat: An historic feast to raise funds for Water Aid
story:
An historic feast has been revived to raise funds for Water Aid, which helps some of the poorest people in the world.

According to the United Nations, 783 million people do not have access to clean water and almost 2.5 billion do not have access to adequate sanitation.

The Leat Feast, which will take place on Sunday April 26 at the Royal Oak Inn in Meavy, near Yelverton, is claimed to hark back to the completion in 1590 of Sir Francis Drake’s Plymouth Leat – a 17 mile long water channel drawn off the River Meavy on Dartmoor. The leat brought a fresh water supply into the heart of old Plymouth.

History claims that to celebrate the feat of engineering and benevolence, a Leat Feast was held each year in Plymouth.

Appropriately, the Feast will raise funds for WaterAid which aims to provide clean water sources in famine and drought-struck parts of the world.

The event will be led by myself, Mark Lindsey Earley in full Elizabethan costume with performances from acclaimed Dartmoor poet Susan Taylor and David Phillips, founder of “Moor Tours” and “Torbay Investigators of the Paranormal” who will tell traditional folk-tales about Drake in the guise of his alter-ego “The Dartmoor Devil”.

For more information on the Leat Feast Revival visit http://www.facebook.com/#!/groups/114868685308099/members/ or contact Mark Lindsey Earley on marklindseyearley@yahoo.co.uk

pageSummaryWhat: I am climbing a mountain with a group of people
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

It would be nice of you to donate some money to water aid because a lot of people in poor, developing countries don't have enough clean water to survive. A lot of children can't go to school because they have to spend their day finding clean water; this means that they can't have a proper education and get a good job. Most children get ill because of the dirty water they are drinking which gives them diseases so they can't live a long and happy life like all of us can. By donating some money would be helping the people have long and healthy lives with a lot more clean water.

I have chosen this charity because an important part of the story I will read on my Batmitzvah is about giving water to a thirsty servant and his camels. The servant has to chose a wife for his masters son. The wife will be the one who will offer to draw water for the camels and the servant.

Just have a think, are you kind enough to give someone a glass of water or let them use your toilet? If you are then donate some money it is exactly the same thing.

Thanks for reading this,                                                                                                          Maya

pageSummary: Rowing across The Atlantic in my self-built skiff because its a great charity, transforming lives every day.
pageSummaryWhat: Rowing across The Atlantic in my self-built skiff
story:
In 2018 I plan to embark on what will undoubtedly be the toughest challenge of my life. For WaterAid, I aim to complete a 3,500 mile solo-row across the North Atlantic Ocean from New York to Lochinver (North West Scotland), in a self-built, clinker style skiff converted for ocean rowing.

After years of researching and pondering over the idea, I have finally come to the conclusion that I'm not getting any younger, so now is the time to put 'pen to paper' or in this case 'oar to water'!

I've been building the boat, at my home, for the past year, as cost effectively as humanly possible - it's been a real labour of love. It is now complete, only the last remaining safety gear and fittings to go. I am beyond excited about this project – as are my friends and family – because my ultimate aim is to raise significant funds for the internationally recognised and respected company, WaterAid. I have been corresponding with WaterAid management/administration - they have been enthusiastic throughout and are keen to see this fundraiser go ahead. This is where you may be able to help!

During the last few months I have been making a huge effort to attract sponsors – individuals, businesses and other organisations. I am passionate about and committed to this challenge – this reflects my feelings for and belief in the amazing work of WaterAid – something I think I might share with you. I hope that you will consider helping me to meet my challenge and, so, contribute to WaterAid’s invaluable ongoing efforts.

I will start the challenge in May 2018 in New York and hope to arrive at Lochinver Harbour 90-100 days later. In the meantime there is much to be done: completion of the boat, testing equipment, fitness training, navigation study etc. This is a heads-up to anyone who would like to follow my progress and wants to offer any support, in the form of donation, time or spreading the word - please share!

FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/duncanadrift/

WEBSITE: https://duncanadrift.com

NORTHERN TIMES FRONT PAGE FEATURE: https://www.northern-times.co.uk/News/Lochinver-man-to-row-the-Atlantic-19102017.htm


Thanks for reading, it's greatly appreciated.

Duncan

pageSummary: Setting Sail to pit ourselves against the elements because Water is the Source of Life
pageSummaryWhat: Setting Sail to pit ourselves against the elements
story:
A Jacobs London Sailing Crew will take the yacht ‘Bluebird’ out into the waters off the west coast of Scotland as part of the fund-raising Clyde Marine Challenge; this self-funded sailing trip takes our intrepid explorers from Largs to Rothesay and Tarbert and back to Largs in three days between 11th and 13th September!

Over the past several years, Jacobs Sailing events on the Clyde have raised over £30,000 for charity, principally WaterAid, which works in partnership with local organisations to help communities establish sustainable water supplies and sanitation close to home. However, with one in eight people worldwide are living without safe water – there is still much more to do.

If you would like to support your crew in their endeavours, please donate through this webpage.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never share them with anyone or send you unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. They'll make sure Gift Aid (an additional 25%) is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer, too. That means more money goes to the charity, faster, with JustGiving.

Many thanks for your support

story:
Hi Everyone

As the 3rd anniversary without Steven approaches, Stephanie & Mia decided that they would like to do something significant to mark the occasion.  Steven's love of cycling is their motivation to join the Pedal for Scotland, Glasgow to Edinburgh cycle, a mere 50 miles!  They decided to support his favourite charity WaterAid, which is also supported by Scottish Water (where Steven worked). 

WaterAid has teams in 37 countries across the world, including Scotland, working to transform millions of lives every year by improving access to safe drinking water, sanitation and hygiene.

Mia and Stephanie would be really grateful if you could help support them on their quest to make Steven very proud.

Joining Stephanie & Mia on the occasion are Lorraine, Aaron, Hazel, Jack, Andy & Kieran - aka - Steven's Pedalling Stars!  Mia, Aaron, Jack and Kieran are age 13 and under so it is quite an undertaking for their wee legs.

pageSummary: I am suggesting donations because dirty water and poor sanition kills children
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

For the past few weeks over 300,000 homes in Lancashire have been advised to boil their drinking water as evidence of the parasite cryptosporidium was found in our supply. United Utilities have now promised to send each household a cheque to the value of £50-60 as compensation for this inconvenience.

From a personal point of view, having to boil the kettle a couple more times each day and buying a few more bottles of water has been a mild irritant rather than a true problem. This seems to be the view of most of my local friends too.

However, millions of people in the world's poorest countries don't have access to safe drinking water and adequate  sanitation and this  kills more than 1,400 children every day. 

If you, like me, have not  been too inconvenienced  by the  water problems perhaps you will consider donating some of your compensation to help those whose water supply is not going to be made safe to drink in the next few days.

Thank you.
