pageSummary: Give back and GLOW.....true 'WELL'being because its vital that EVERY body has clean water.
story:
THANK YOU so much for taking the time to visit my 'WELL'ness page. The original aim was to encourage as many people as possible to make a small donation every time they have a spa or beauty treatment. In addition, we've got people involved in a WELLness Walk, the first was on 7th May in Altrincham . The response was fantastic, 50 people came on the walk. Everyone raised money and we're hoping the total will help Wateraid fund at least 40 wells - all in one day, which is a-maze-ing!!  Hopefully it will become an annual event as the feedback has been so positive with everyone loving the chance to get out in the fresh air (and sunshine!) catch up with friends and raise money for such a worthwhile cause.The benefit of our project is that whilst you're looking after your own health and wellness, YOU are providing clean water for those in real need across the globe. Together we can fund the building of wells for those that are dying from unclean water.....it gives real meaning to the terms 'WELLness' and 'WELLbeing'. Imagine what we could achieve if we all encouraged our friends to donate -  we could actually save lives. If you make a donation to help people in need,  this act of genuine kindness can give you an ''inner glow' , which in turn can enhance the feeling of well-being. As a result, you should get much more from your treatment ( ... or walk!) The more you look after yourself, the more you help those in genuine need, a 'Give back and GLOW' approach. Also, if you comment on how good the spa /salon was,  we can spread the word, promote the establishment and enhance the industry.... so everyone does WELL, a real win/win/win! ...or Well, Well, Well ! ( sorry!)

The facts - 650 million people live without safe water. Every day 1400 children die from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation, that's over 500, 000 each year .....and we are so lucky to have enough clean water that we can swim in it!  
A while ago I remember seeing a cartoon where a little boy from a third world country looks on incredulously at a child from the developed world, and says ....'....so your water is so clean, that you poo in it ? ? ( ...or words to that effect !) ...it sounds crazy that the water we flush in our toilets is much, much cleaner than the water many people drink each day. Also, when we visit a spa we are so lucky to be able to bathe, swim, float, exercise and relax in water that is sparkling clean, whereas millions of people are drinking unsafe water and dying as a result. It really hit home that it's such an unequal, unfair world, and that if possible, we should be doing all we can to improve this dire situation - to prevent 1400 children dying unnecessarily today. Because the spa industry is based around the health-giving benefits of water, I felt that WaterAid was the perfect charity partner, and together we could all make a difference in the world, whilst enhancing our own WELLness and that of our clients. True WELLbeing in action.

To make it really quick and simple - download the Justgiving App, then it's simply a few taps (taps!) to donate ...don't forget to tell us how wonderful the spa/salon/therapist was and tick the gift aid box so we raise even more ....thank you!

(Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity)

story: Thank you for taking time to visit this page. Although it's only a minor temporary lifestyle change, I will be eradicating 70% of my diet for a month and this may drive me to be slightly insane and/or a little bit more boring. However, I must stress the importance of WaterAid's work. WaterAid is a charity that makes sanitation, safe water and hygiene education more accessible to the many surrounded by poverty; basic human rights that generates a more healthy and educated climate. Considering more than 1.3 billion manage to live without effective sanitation, living without a depressant will probably be quite achievable for me. If you can support WaterAid through this page, it would be really appreciated. Thank you!

pageSummary: I am turning 40 on 14th February and raising money because *please read my story-too long to say why here!*
pageSummaryWhat: I am turning 40 on 14th February and raising money
story:
Dearest family, friends, friends of friends...this is the biggest appeal I've ever made..

In 3 weeks time, on 14 February I will be celebrating my 40th birthday. During this past week I've been thinking of all the wonderful people who have made a positive impact on my life, feeling grateful for the many blessings that I have, for my amazing family, my husband and sweet precious children.. And I've thought, as a great number of you live all around the world, how do I have a party to celebrate and say thank you for what you've meant in my life?

So I've decided not to have a party, but rather to celebrate life by raising money for a charity close to my heart..but now which one would that be? I could choose one that relates to my beloved parents who died way too young..my Dad aged 52 due to mental illness, so do I choose a charity that supports people with that disease? Or a cancer charity, given that my Mum died of colon cancer aged 58 and that I have so many friends and family who have won or lost the battle? Or do I choose a charity that supports vulnerable children as I am eternally grateful that I have three healthy and happy children? It would also need to be an international charity..so that it's relevant to all of you, in your own part of the world and so that you know that you ARE making a difference by donating.

Today I came across an article that I could barely read through my tears.. Seven pregnant woman, profiled by the international charity WaterAid, revealed the "essentials" they will pack in their "hospital bag", things that they will need during labour.. The lady from New York packed a Bose music player, eye mask and coconut massage oil, and spoke of how new life is a true miracle, about wanting the best for your baby and how it's devastating to think about dangers such as contaminated water and unhygienic facilities; a lady from Malawi packed a razor blade and string to cut and tie her own umbilical cord and a black plastic bag to put over the hospital bed, knowing that there is no clean running water and that the bed would not have been cleaned from the previous delivery; a lady from Melbourne, originally from the UK and who lived in Malawi for 2 years, had the most kitted out and well organised bag, and said how she thought it was unbelievable that heavily pregnant women are collecting dirty water themselves, carrying 25 litres over a considerable distance; the lady from London packed Haribo sweets, mini iPad and an empty water bottle, and said she's assuming the hospital will have a water fountain where she can fill it. Another lady, from Tanzania packed a (dirty) plastic basin for her to wash herself after the birth..none of the rooms in the labour ward have basins or any provision of water..women have to wash in the toilet or climb into the sink in the sluice room to wash after giving birth. Sitting in the comfort of my home and remembering the awesome experience of the birth of my babies, it was horrific to read the raw truth of just how very different the delivery of new life happens in different places around the world.

I then went onto the WaterAid website to read more about its DELIVER LIFE appeal. And I read another horrific thing: Every minute a newborn baby dies from an infection caused by a lack of safe water and unclean environment.. Can you believe that that happens? Every minute!

So my chosen charity, to celebrate the 40th year of my life, is WaterAid, and in particular its DELIVER LIFE appeal..through our donations we can support the delivery of the most basic need that a new life should have access to..and that is clean water.
The DELIVER LIFE appeal's strap line is Deliver Hope, Deliver Joy, Deliver Life. Those of you who know me well will know that in the last couple of years, I've been so grateful for renewed Joy and Hope in my life which has helped me cope with the loss of my parents. I think my parents would approve of my choice of charity!

Please help me make a difference by donating to WaterAid. I've set a target of £4,000 (can you see the "40" in there!) And I'm going to kick off the donations with what we could've spent on a party here in Edinburgh and that has the number 4 in it.. It would be awesome if you could donate any amount that includes the number 4 in it. Donating through the JustGiving website is so easy and you'd be donating in your local currency, any amount will make a difference.
And, to make our donations reach even more mums and babies, the UK Government has pledged that until 10 February (ha, 4 days before my birthday!) it will match every £ donated by us to WaterAid..so NOW is the time to give!

God bless you all and thank you so very much - for your donation of course, and also for your friendships, for the laughs and happy times we've shared together, for the sad ones too, the tears and the sharing of great loss, for your support, encouragement, for your positive affirmation, for the very things I wish I could to turn to my parents for and am blessed to find in you. With much love, Riki

Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: I am only drinking water for a whole month! because We take water for granted!
pageSummaryWhat: I am only drinking water for a whole month!
story:
For the month of march 2016... I WILL ONLY BE DRINKING WATER! That means no fizzy, no tea, no squash, no milk and definitely no alcohol!

Only cold, hot and room-temperature still water allowed.

water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: A Close Shave for Clean Water
pageSummary: I am shaving my head because every day lives are lost from lack of clean water
story:
Hello, my name is Peggie-Ann and on 2nd April 2016, I will be shaving my head to raise money for WaterAid.

WaterAid is an international non governmental organisation focused exclusively on improving access to safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation in some of the world’s poorest communities. WaterAid works in Africa, Asia and the Pacific region and campaigns globally to realise our vision of a world where everyone has access to safe water and sanitation.

Please help me to work towards a world where everyone can have access to clean, safe water.

Just £15 can give the life-changing gift of clean water to one person. See what else your donation could provide:

* £12 can buy two taps for a village water point.
* £15 can give the gift of water to one person.
* £20 can buy 25 metres of pipe.
* £46 can buy a family toilet.
* £50 can buy a handpump.
* £60 can buy a rainwater collection jar
* £100 can help two people set up a soap making business.


Every day 1,400 children die from drinking dirty water - That means, since you started reading this, at least one more child will have died. So please, dig deep and help me hit my target!


Thank you.

Peggie-Ann

pageSummary: We are flying a microlight from Paris to Dakar because pure clean water should be there for everyone
pageSummaryWhat: We are flying a microlight from Paris to Dakar
story:
The aim of this flight is to keep the spirit of the original race alive in a difficult age, by flying the Paris-Dakar route by microlight. At the same time, it hopes to raise significant funds for WaterAid, which is working to provide clean water and sanitation for millions of the world’s poorest people.

Julian and Sarah (Jezz) are flying by microlight through France and Spain to Morocco. Then on, through the politically disputed territory of Western Sahara and Mauritania to Senegal - 3280 miles

pageSummary: Face painting at Gina Conway WBG salon! because Safe drinking water should be for all!
pageSummaryWhat: Face painting at Gina Conway WBG salon!
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Please if you can donate - a little will go a long way all the profit will go to Water Aid to help provide  safe drinking water!

On the 24th April I will be face painting at the Gina Conway Salon in westbound grove - All the money from this will go to water aid.

Some facts - Diarrhoea caused by dirty water and bad sanitation is the second biggest child killer worldwide. A lack of clean water and toilets keeps girls out of school, stops women from working, and traps people in poverty.

Water air-tackle the crisis from all angles. They work with local partners to deliver clean water and toilets and promote good hygiene, and campaign to make change happen for everyone everywhere.

pageSummary: Raising money by walking/swimming/running/cycling because they help to prevent disease and suffering
story:
In 2015, our aim was to travel virtually 5,953 miles (9,581 km) from London to Ethiopia, where our corporate donations are already providing safe water and sanitation to thousands of people.
We beat our target and travelled 25,928 miles (41,726 kilometres), the earth's circumference at the equator.  

This year, we are aiming to travel virtually to travel across countries where we have offices, a total of 46,366 miles (74,618 km), in the same period of time 6 weeks!

The De-Vice Squad consists of Teresa Perry, Paul Mayon, Richard Tully, Malcolm Goodall, Cheryl O'Rourke and Andrew Cartwright, from the Medical Device Delivery and QMS teams.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
Hello everyone as I'm sure you're aware Alice, Charis and I recently organised the Nelson House Charity Dinner on Friday 6 May in aid of Water Aid a charity very close to our hearts. We have created this page for those of you who were unable to come but still wish to donate!

In a world where we depend so much on material goods and the latest technological advances, it is hard to believe that so many people go without a fundamental necessity of life: water. Two and a half billion people still don’t have access to adequate sanitation – this is a shocking statistic and we are determined to do all that we can to make a positive change.

Water Aid is working hard in more than 37 countries to provide clean, safe water to the poorest and most marginalised people in our world. Not only do they improve access to water sanitation and hygiene in the short term they also implement community-led solutions to help empower local communities and educate them about the benefits of clean water so that they can continue Water Aid’s work in the long run helping to free themselves from the lives of poverty in which they are trapped. Their target is to give everyone, everywhere, access to clean water by 2030. This will be a huge challenge, but one which we believe to be achievable.

When considering poverty in the developing world, many people feel deep sorrow but conclude that there is nothing we can do. While poverty is indeed extreme and wide- spread, it is easy to forget just how many people there are in the developed world, and how powerful our pocket change can become when pooled together.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Therefore we'd really appreciate your donations and thankyou so much for everyone's support!

Eleanor :)

pageSummary: Emelia and her family want to raise at least £50 because children in the world need toilets and clean water
pageSummaryWhat: Emelia and her family want to raise at least £50
story:
So we were watching television a few weeks ago and saw an advert for WaterAid. Emelia and Liesl were struck by the little girl carrying the heavy jerry can of water, so we talked about it. Thanks to her Godfather Uncle Hallam, we got in touch with WaterAid and set up a little project for her.

She wants to raise £50. That's her goal. We'll take donations from the sale of our soaps at today's school Summer Fete and send to WaterAid via this JustGiving page. I've got a lot of surplus blocks of soap from trial batches, as I get my fledgling business off the ground, so I'm taking donations in exchange for the lovely, bubbly, if slightly imperfect bars. We'll take some photos of how the day goes and post here when we get back.

Thanks for helping!

pageSummary: Sailing in the Clyde Marine Challenge 2016 because one in ten people are living without safe water
pageSummaryWhat: Sailing in the Clyde Marine Challenge 2016
story:
Right now, some of the world’s poorest and most marginalised people don’t have access to safe water to drink, decent toilets or hygiene. Without these basics, overcoming poverty is just a dream. But when you help WaterAid to dig a well or install a tap stand in a community, everything changes.

Today one in ten people are still living without safe water. But your support could help change everything for a community – in a single day.

The Rotary Club of Rothesay is supporting the Clyde Marine Challenge 2016 by entering two yachts and raise funds for WaterAid.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never pass them on or send unwanted emails. Water Aid is the charity I’m raising money for. One of our

pageSummary: I am raising money because I want everyone in the world to have water.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

My idea is fairly simple and straightforward. I draw a picture and if you would like it I will happily sell it you but with the payment going directly to Water Aid instead of me. I usually charge £50 for my drawings including the frame but I am now dropping my asking price to £30 minimum excluding the frame. Of course if you want to pay more that is fine but £30 is the lowest amount I will accept. 

If you would like a frame or an item posted abroad this can be arranged in a personal Facebook message or on here. Please be aware I may ask for a separate direct payment to me if this is the case but this can be discussed/arranged. 

Once a drawing has been arranged and finished and you are happy with it you can simply donate on here and then inform me in a message on here or on Facebook. Then we can arrange collection or posting.

pageSummary: Ken Hutchison will be braving the Shark Tank because they help transform lives with water & sanitation
pageSummaryWhat: Ken Hutchison will be braving the Shark Tank
story:
Ken has recently passed his PADI diving certficate and has agreed to put it to the test in the Shark Tank at Deep Sea World if we raise enough money! Whilst comfortable in the Water Ken is not friendly with Sharks so we need your donations to convince him to do it! 

If you want to see me swimming with sharks, please donate - even a pound will make a difference, it all adds up!

Supporters will be able to see photos and a message from me after the dive.  The largest donation will receive a ticket to attend the event (including a free tour of the aquarium).

WaterAid help the world's poorest communities transform their lives with clean water.  To give you an idea of the scale of the problem, 1 in 10 people don't have access to safe water and 1 in 3 people don't have access to adequate sanitation.

We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030.  Together we make that happen

pageSummary: Rob Mustard will be braving the Shark Tank because they help transform lives with water & sanitation.
pageSummaryWhat: Rob Mustard will be braving the Shark Tank
story:
In 2015, I had the opportunity to visit Africa with WaterAid and experience first-hand, the challenges faced by people on a daily basis.  The lack of basic drinking water and sanitation was heart-breaking.  I am keen to support and raise awareness of WaterAid and it's work in any way I can and as such, I'm willing to brave the Shark Tank at Deep Sea World (with Ken Hutchinson) if we raise enough money.  Funnily enough, I'm not that comfortable around sharks so any donations will help convince me to do it!

If you want to see me swimming with sharks, please donate - even a pound will make a difference, it all adds up!

Supporters will be able to see photos and a message from me after the dive. The largest donation will receive a ticket to attend the event (including a free tour of the aquarium).

WaterAid help the world's poorest communities transform their lives with clean water.  To give you an idea of the scale of the problem, 1 in 10 people don't have access to safe water and 1 in 3 people don't have access to adequate sanitation.

We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030.  Together we make that happen!

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As you gather from the title, I will be completing various challenges this year to raise money for WaterAid.  These will vary in degrees of difficulty plus all the events I enter will have been paid for by myself so anything you donate on the site will go straight to WaterAid and will not subsidise any of the events I have planned and entered.

List of Challenges so far;

  • January - Just Water (WaterAid's very own challenge of substituting all drinks to water, no more early morning fruit smoothies or coffee for me for the next 2 weeks) Link for info - http://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/events/just-water - COMPLETED
  • March - Cambridge Half Marathon - Official time 2:01:17 - COMPLETED
  • May 7th - Wings For Life World Run  - Ran in Cambridge again, target of 10 miles before I got caught by the chaser car! - COMPLETED
  • May 17th - Trekking in Peru - Salkantay Pass (4600 meters) through blizzard conditions and 5 days of trekking leading to Machu Picchu. Huayna Picchu climbed as well - COMPLETED
  • July 8th - Grafham Water Open water swim (750m) - My first foray into open water swimming. No expectation on times, just finishing will be my goal - COMPLETED in 23 minutes
  • August 18/19th - National 3 peaks Challenge 24 hours, Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon - weather and transport permitting. COMPLETED (unfortunately, Scottish wildlife had other plans for us not to finish it in 24 hours)
  • Sept 8/9th - Thames Path Challenge 100km - Starting from Putney bridge London walking in 24 hours (ish) to Henley COMPLETED in 19 hours 27 minutes
  • Sept 23/24th - Equinox24 Joined a team of 4 to run a 10K course as much as possible in a relay race - COMPLETED  total of 210km ran in 24 hrs.  3 did 50km whilst the fitter one did 60km.
  • Oct 28th - Tough Sh!t WaterAid's very own muddy challenge - Completed but was tough on the old knees (rest needed).
  • Month of December - Carrying Water from my home to my place of work (1 mile away) for the days I am in work (got a couple of days off) - going to be an advent style challenge so increasing 1 litre everyday (upto max 20 litres).

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:

I'm a bit late to the game because I only found out about it today so I will be doing 4 weeks drinking only water from tomorrow (6/1-2/2) Should be a piece of pee, without caffeine I'll sleep though it!

If anyone is interested in making my pain worthwhile making a small donation to Water Aid my just giving page is below.

Now I'm going to make myself a MAHOOSIVE coffee while
I still can :)

pageSummary: I am Gregor Walker, in P7 at Donobristle Primary because I hate the fact that people don't have clean water
pageSummaryWhat: I am Gregor Walker, in P7 at Donobristle Primary
story:
I have been growing my hair for a few months now, inspired by our family Friend Lewis Robertson who also grew his hair to raise money for charity. I will be donating my cut hair to the Little Princess Trust, who provide real hair wigs, free of charge, to boys and girls across the UK and Ireland that have lost their own hair through cancer treatment.

I want to give my hair to help make these wigs but also to raise money by asking people to sponsor me to grow my hair so long and have it cut in one of our school assemblies, just before I go to Ardroy Outdoor Education Centre in March.

I intend to split any money I raise between the Little Princess Trust, Ardroy and another charity we have been learning about at School, Water aid. I have set myself a target of £150 to start.

The Little Princess Trust is a children’s cancer charity and our mission is to supply real hair wigs to children suffering with cancer, for the duration of their treatment.  However, in addition we assist children with other conditions which also result in hair loss, the most common being alopecia.  Our commitment to these children is different.  Despite being set up to help children with cancer, the Trust is able to supply children that do not have a cancer diagnosis with a single wig.  Whilst we are unable to commit to supplying more than one wig, we hope that this gesture will help the child and family whilst they decide on their long-term plans for dealing with this sort of condition.

Ardroy Outdoor Education Centre is a multi-activity residential facility situated in Lochgoilhead, Scotland. We have been in operation since 1969, and can accommodate over 70 people. We run school, youth, adult courses, and more!
Most attendees are primary school children - we work with local authorities across Scotland and beyond. Youth groups, colleges, charities, and businesses use our services too. We also work with adult groups, whether for leisure or learning. Our activities achieve a range of learning outcomes, in particular those set out for school pupils in the Curriculum for Excellence.

WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

pageSummaryWhat: We are drinking JUST WATER from 01/04 - 01/07
story:
***WE HAVE EXTENDED OUR CHALLENGE TO 3 MONTHS***

Every minute, every day, people suffer and lives are lost needlessly because of a lack of safe water and sanitation. Help us end this global crisis and transform lives.

Just Water means cutting out all drinks except for one – water. No coffee, tea or juice, and none of those sugary and fruity drinks!

WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet.

We would greatly appreciate your support as we have one drink for 3 months!!

pageSummary: If its not water then I am not drinking it because I really want a cup of tea and need to keep focus
pageSummaryWhat: If its not water then I am not drinking it
story:
I have set myself a different personal challenge for each month of 2017 as well as running every day for the whole year.  I've successfully completed Dry January, Vegan Feb and no sugary treats March.  This month, if its not water then I am not drinking it.

Now, I really like tea.  And wine.  I REALLY like wine. And tea.  Hmmmm... tea and wine.  But NO, I can't have either until 1st May 2017!  This is turning out to be really hard and miserable. I am continually thinking about cheating!!!  In order to guilt me in to staying true to my goal, I think I need to raise money and it seems appropriate to raise money for WaterAid since, in my privileged little bubble, I am actually lucky to have something as dull as clean water to drink all month long.

WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.  1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water.

(See... even setting this up, I feel like a dickhead for thinking about cheating.)

pageSummary: NA
story:
Making Waves MWH  is taking part in WaterAid's Water Innovators employee development challenge. This year's challenge focuses on water, sanitation and hygiene-promotion problems  in Nicaragua where 800, 000 people don't have access to clean, safe water and two million live with out access to proper sanitation. 

We have an exciting schedule of fundraising events coming up to raise over £5000 for WaterAid projects in Nicuragua but we need your help! Together we can work to provide the basic human right to clean water and sanitation in communities that need it the most.

Thank you so much for your support!

Marianne, Erin, Matthew, Samuel, John, Mehtaab, Jonny and Hiba.

 For more information about WaterAid and the Water Innovators challenge please visit: http://www.wateraid.org/uk

pageSummary: Raising money
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

﻿The Global NRM Team work very hard everyday for Diageo and we are proud of being part of this very important commercial transformation. However, we felt we wanted to give something back, for others and ourselves.

We are raising money to support our partner charity WaterAid who do some fantastic work in helping transforming thousands of lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation in many developing countries around the world. Please visit their website for more details.

﻿http://wateraid.org

In support of Water Aid we came up with 18 4 18. Our target is to raise £1800 by the end of FY18, delivering 18 individual achievements. Below are a few examples of the challenges we have set ourselves in our team:

Learn Guitar /complete 100k cycle race Climb a mountain above 3500mCreate a food blog Organise an NRM gig Create a cook bookComplete Mexican half marathon under 4 hours Complete 100km bike ride
Our ask for you is to help us reach our £1800 target, its a lot of money, but for a very good cause. We will need your support if we are going to get there!

Thank you!

The Global NRM Team

pageSummary: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For 365 days, I am drinking tap water and only tap water* in order to raise awareness and cash for WaterAid, a charity that provides clean water for drinking and sanitation to those who need it most. The knock-on effect of access to clean water is unbelievable, and essential in the journey out of poverty.

I want to challenge myself to make a small sacrifice which is really just the tip of the iceberg when addressing how we live in relation to the lives of others, as , for so many, water on tap would be a luxury and a miracle.

If you are able, please donate to the essential work of WaterAid.

If you're intrigued, please join me in the JustWater challenge for a day/week/month/year!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

*bottled water when outside the UK.

pageSummary: trekking 100k in 5 days deep in the Arctic circle because 663m people live without clean water to drink!
pageSummaryWhat: trekking 100k in 5 days deep in the Arctic circle
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In August 2018, 100 HSBC employees will trek 100km over 5 days deep in the Arctic Circle in order to raise a combined (HSBC matched) total of $500k for Water Aid.

﻿663 million people live without clean water to drink....that is around 10% of the world's population!

2.4 billion don't have access to adequate sanitation.

800 children die every day from diseases caused by a lack of safe water, sanitation and hygiene.

The HSBC Water Programme funds projects in six countries: Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Ghana and Nigeria

pageSummary: I am going to Trek 100km across Greenland because clean water is essential for life.....
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to Trek 100km across Greenland
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am planning to Trek 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland for 5-6 days along with up to 100 of my HSBC colleagues from around the world to raise vital funds for WaterAid.  As the world's largest island, Greenland is the least densely populated territory in the world with a population of less than 60,000, the trek will take us through untamed land, some of which is untouched by human civilization.

With 80% of landmass covered in ice, we will trek across multiple terrains such as tundra and glaciers while camping in cold conditions, surviving on basic meals and cut off from all modern conveniences we take for granted.  This remote expedition is not for the faint hearted.... :-)

Help me in this journey of exploration for myself, my colleagues and to help make a difference in this world.  Just because you can't be there with me...doesn't mean I won't be taking a part of all of you with me, in knowing that you are supporting my journey.

﻿﻿﻿﻿Thank you for your for your thoughts, prayers and donations!

    ~  Jeanne

Did you know.......water is becoming a more scarce resource.  In less than two years, two-thirds of the world's population could be living under water stressed conditions.      

﻿﻿

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: 100km Arctics Expedition in Greenland because I believe access to clean water is human right!
story:
今年八月，我要和99位來自世界各地的同事一起到格陵蘭健行100公里。五天期間要負重10公斤、睡帳篷，沒有網路、不能洗澡。參加動機，除了喜歡戶外活動外，也是想為世界盡一份力。

我們是為了幫助無法取得乾淨水/廁所/衛生的人而走，每個參加者都會為非營利組織WaterAid募款至少三萬多台幣。

我在此邀請大家一起響應，千元不嫌多，百元不嫌少。

每一筆都是祝福，每一筆都是力量。謝謝你們~

=======================================================

I am visiting Greenland this August! I will join 99 other colleagues globally to trek 100 km in the Arctics. There will be no internet access nor shower available. The trek is to raise fund for NPO WaterAid, which is established since July 1981 and aims to reach everyone, everywhere with clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene.

You are invited to share your blessings. Be it hundreds USD or tens, every donation counts! Thanks!

=======================================================

In diesem Sommer bin ich in Grönland und gehe mit 99 anderen Kollegen 100 km in 5 Tagen auf der Arktis. Ich mache Mittelbeschaffung wegen dieser Veranstaltung für NPO WaterAid. Die NPO bietet den Menschen, die kein sauberes Wasser oder Toilette haben, diese. Es gibt mehr Leute, die Handys haben als die, die sauberes Wasser haben. 

Falls du helfen möchtest, könntest du auf JustGiving spenden! JustGiving ist ein Crowdfunding Plattform, das NPO hilft zu sammeln. Vielen Dank.

pageSummary: I'm diving with the sharks because I'm Aquaman - a Water & Sanitation Superhero!
story:
I got involved in WaterAid through my work with Scottish Water. My first event was attending and sponsoring the WaterAid Scotland 2016 ball.  I am proud to say that I became the owner of the world's first WaterAid tartan kilt after a successful bid in the silent auction. The tartan continues to grow with it's own event the Tartan Trail, and people from Prince Charles to Sir Ranulph Fiennes being owners of WaterAid tartan ties. I'm proud to be part of that legacy. 

My affinity with WaterAid has grown and grown since then. In the picture above I'm posing with Team Tartan at the WaterAid ball 2017. Pictured are Ewan Robertson, Vice-Chair of WaterAid Scotland and Chairman Ken Hutchison. In the picture below we can see the happy winner of the car I donated as star prize raffle. No, it wasn't a fix! She just happened to be wearing a matching dress!

I am passionate about supporting wateraid and I've pro-active in supporting all the events. However, this is my first own personal challenge with WaterAid and my first personal fundraiser. I'm proud to be in good company - I'll be diving with Ken Hutchison and Rob Mustard, Director of Digital in Scottish Water. I've been advised that Sharks like Mustard and Ken-tchup on their dinner - so I'll hopefully be alright!

WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: 100km Arctic Expedition trek in Greenland because more people own a mobile phone than a toilet
story:
WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

Greenland - the world's largest island, 80% of which is covered in ice and is the world's least densely populated territory. Our trek will involve visiting the shrinking ice sheet (10bn tons of ice melts annually due to climate change). We will then trek across 100km of Arctic tundra over the next 5 days, taking advantage of 22 hours of daylight, to make it back to civilisation and the coast. We will camp on the tundra and carry our gear and supplies on our backs.

Some others facts that highlight the scale of the global water crisis:

2.4bn people don't have access to adequate sanitation

663mn people live without clean drinking water

800 children die every day from disease which is a direct result of lack of safe water

WaterAid works with governments and local organisations to deliver water, sanitation and hygiene to communities that most need it.﻿﻿

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
This Christmas season, I’m helping to champion WaterAid Canada's 2017 Holiday Campaign.

This year’s campaign focuses on changing the truly deplorable water
and sanitation conditions in the West African country of Mali, where every year 4,000 children under age 5 die needlessly from diarrhea caused by dirty water. 

Support provided through this year’s Holiday Campaign, will help WaterAid to initiate a new project to reach 35,600 people with clean water, 24,300 with basic sanitation and 72,500 with hygiene
promotion activities in the impoverished districts of Bla and Kati.  

Transforming lives with clean water and safe, private toilets is just the beginning of how your gift will help. When people have water and toilets they can finally lay the foundations for a better life, people fall sick less often, children have time to play and go to school; men and women can build their livelihoods and spend time with their loved ones. People’s health, prosperity, dignity and hope are no longer limited by a lack of water and toilets. I truly cannot think of a better gift to give to some of the world’s poorest communities.

I’m seeking to raise $15,000 to before December 31st to directly
support WaterAid’s Mali: Healthy Communities project and I
hope that you will consider helping me reach my goal.

To learn more about the project being supported through this campaign effort, please visit www.wateraidcanada.com/campaign 

Every £1 donated by UK residents between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

Thank you!

I am a 2nd year student at the University of Glasgow and i am giving up alcohol for the month of January in order to raise money forthis great cause!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Trekking across the Arctic Circle in Greenland
pageSummaryWhat: Trekking across the Arctic Circle in Greenland
story:
For those who know me well it probably won't surprise you that I'm trying something new and exploring a new corner of this crazy world however this is a massive challenge for me all the same.  On 3rd August 2018, I will be trekking 100km across the Arctic Circle in Greenland alongside 99 of my HSBC colleagues from all across the world to raise money for WaterAid.  I'll have no access to my usual luxuries, no shower, a proper bed or normal toilet.  In addition, I will be carrying all of my personal belongings and camping equipment over the 5 days we have to complete the trek.  With an average of 22 hours of daylight per day at least my chances look promising :-) 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. 844 million people don’t have clean water. 

So please dig deep to help this great cause and challenge me to go through the ultimate test of mental and physical ability.

pageSummary: I am trekking 100km within the Arctic Circle because everyone should have access to safe water
pageSummaryWhat: I am trekking 100km within the Arctic Circle
story:
﻿Around the world, 1 in 10 people don't have access to safe water. Every day 800 children die from diseases caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation. WaterAid is saving and transforming people's lives with clean water.﻿﻿

In August, I'll be joining 99 HSBC colleagues on a 100km trek in the Arctic Circle in Greenland to raise funds. Entirely self-funded, we'll be hiking for five days, carrying our own equipment and camping out in one of world's least populated territories.

I'm trying to raise at least £3,000 in sponsorship, which will help provide safe water for 136 people. Please give what you can.

With thanks for your support, Joe

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
﻿I am joining 99 HSBC colleagues around the world to trek 100km over 5 days deep in the Arctic Circle across Greenland, the world largest island to raise money for Water Aid.

Water AID is a great cause and can help raise awareness and money for those who need clean water and also keep our water safe including understanding the issues we are facing, challenges and impact.

It is a global crisis! There are 663 million people who live without clean water to drink, that is around 10% of the worlds population. 2.4 million don't have access to adequate sanitation. 800 children die every day from diseases caused by a lack of safe water, sanitation and hygiene.

The trek will take us through untamed land, some of which are untouched by human civilisation. 

Personally, this will be a once in a lifetime opportunity to help those in need and I am ready for the challenge!﻿

Your donation (big or small) will help make a HUGE difference. The trek = access to clean water for 26000 people and HSBC will match the donation amount.

Thank you for your support and donation.

﻿

pageSummary: Cutting off my bread I've had for almost 3 years!
pageSummaryWhat: Cutting off my bread I've had for almost 3 years!
story:
for almost the last 3 years I have had a beard; all that is about to change! in preparation for this year's no shave November I'm going to play fair and shave it all off! 100% of proceeds from this event will go to Wateraid. WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. They want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen. At our goal of £472 they will provide a Wheel and rope pump, providing water for up too 120 people!

at 50% of our goal I aim to live-stream the whole event and if logistics allow an edited video will be posted showing the event in a more condensed version!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
On 3rd August 2018, I will be trekking over 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland as part of a group of 100 HSBC colleagues. With no access to a shower, 'proper' toilet or the outside world, I will be carrying all of my personal equipment and camping gear for 5 days and will be roughing it in one of the most remote places in the world to raise money for WaterAid.

I am extremely fortunate to have been given the opportunity to participate in this challenge. All donations will go directly to the charity. Any expenses for this trip will be covered personally.

Currently 663million people (10% of the world's population) live without safe water and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. WaterAid aims to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, and hopes to give everyone safe access to water by 2030, so please dig dip and sponsor this worthy cause!

story:
In August 2018, myself and 99 colleagues are going to trek
100km in 5 days across the Arctic in Greenland to raise money for
WaterAid.  We'll be trekking across tundra and glaciers, surviving on basic meals, camping in tents, with no access to home comforts or showers, to bring attention to and raise money for this cause.

WaterAid is a non-profit organisation which provides access to clean drinking water and sanitation throughout the developing world. Hitting our fundraising target for this challenge will hopefully mean we can help over 26,000 people get access to clean water.

pageSummary: NA
story:
To those local families in Bramhall, Cheadle Hulme and Hazel Grove who were affected by the burst water main last Tuesday, have you received
a letter from UU explaining that they will be sending you a cheque for £25 to compensate you for your inconvenience? It’s a nice gesture from UU but we’ve got an idea that will hopefully appeal to many of you and be of tremendous benefit to
countless people in the world who don’t have access to clean drinking water on a daily basis.

We've decided to donate our £25 to Water Aid. Yes, we were mildly inconvenienced as we couldn’t have a shower that morning and we had to go
and buy some bottled water to get us through a few hours, but that was a minor
hardship compared to so many people in the world.

If just 10 families donated some or all of their £25 to Water Aid we could fund 5 water pumps in Nepal or toilets for 8 households in India.

Please give what you can, if you can.

Merry Christmas all x

pageSummary: To raise awarness for safe water and Sanitation because everyone should have access.
pageSummaryWhat: To raise awarness for safe water and Sanitation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

This is Aveda's 7th year in Partnership with Water aid and during this time we have helped to raise over £745k. With this money we have funded projects in Ethiopia, Nepal and India.

Since 2015 we have managed to reach:

60,598 people with access to improved water

55,168 people with access to sanitation

64,545 people with hygiene messages

Every minute, every day people suffer and lives are lost needlessly because lack of safe water and sanitation. Thank you for helping us end this global crisis and transform lives.

﻿

﻿


﻿

story:
Hello my name is Harvey McLeod.

I am a 16 year old boy, who has always wanted to make a change in the world. Personally to have lived in the UK my whole life i have always taken clean water for granted, i have never realized how lucky i am til i came across WaterAids work. Soon as i came across WaterAids work i instantly wanted to do something to help raise money, that is how i came across the idea of shaving my hair. I have always had quite long hairstyles and see my hair as part of who i am. I have been growing my hair currently since April, for it to be shaved for WaterAid. I ask of you to reach deep and do your part to help this cause by donating and supporting my page.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Some people earn less in a day than what we might spend on a cup of tea or coffee, often working in difficult and dangerous conditions with little health and safety regulation or Trade Union support.  We thought it would be good if we could sacrifice our beverage of choice just once a month and give the equivalent (or more if you feel so inclined) to charity.  So every 2nd Friday of the month we are asking you to do just this, starting with Friday 13th January - an easy date to remember!

pageSummaryWhat: Approx 25 mile walk with friends & Family.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 6th may 2017, myself,  family members and friends will be doing approx 25 mile walk to raise funds for Wateraid which was a charity close to Mel's heart after spending many happy holidays in Africa ( Gambia, Tunisia , South Africa , Senegal & Egypt ) Mel always  wanted to go off road to see how the real people lived, not what the tour operators wanted us to see , and once  she was asked to take a school class in The Gambia ( which she refused)  but gave a lot  of praise to the children who showed her their books. And  also loved the work of the orphanage we one visited.

 Please give what you can as every penny will make a difference. Please feel free to share this page.

Thank you.

Wyn. 

Xx

pageSummary: NA
story: Hi everyone, thank you for visiting this JustGiving page set up for Maurice. After we received the horrible news that Maurice had suddenly passed along with Killian and the time came to close his bank account, we discovered that he had been paying monthly to this fantastic charity. Although it was obvious to everyone that knew Maurice that he was a kind and generous person, even we found it very touching that at 19 years of age,  being considered a bit of a party animal and someone who thought money would burn in his pocket, that he was considerate enough to do this and never say a word to anyone about it. It was just one of the kind and considerate thing Maurice done on a daily basis and it is because of this we want to raise this money in his memory. We are having a Night at the Races in his memory for this charity too, which will be held at Fintona Golf Club on 15th April. Everyone is more than welcome and every penny is greatly appreciated. Thank you.
title: Maurice's page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Maurice Mccloughan
Name: Maurice's page

story:
WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.

1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: We are raising money because we want to transform lives
story:
What is the Challenge/Programme?
t’s a programme on behalf of WaterAid that gives us the opportunity
to help WaterAid reach more people with safe water and toilets while getting a
unique learning experience.

WaterAid provide our team with four challenges based on real water,
sanitation and hygiene-promotion problems faced by the WaterAid team in
Nicaragua where 800,000 people don’t have access to clean, safe water, and two
million live without access to a good sanitation

What’s expected of us?
Our team of 7, will be organising fundraising days to raise more than £5000
to support WaterAid projects. Which will then be followed a Dragons’ Den style
pitch in October in London where we present are innovate ideas on one of the 4 challenges listed above.

The overall winning team will get the chance to visit our country programme in Nicaragua

Our team
Charlotte Plumb, Lauren Whitcombe, Adam Simpson, Sebastian Bures, Karen
Horlock, Emily Stevens and Rachel Guild.

Our Company Sponsor
Jim MacIntyre - Head of Operations East (South East Water)

WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have
access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these
basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

story:
Our friend and colleague Katharine Perera died on the first of October. It was her wish that we should not buy flowers for her funeral, but that those who wish to remember her should make a donation to WaterAid. This is one of the ways in which Katharine will keep making a difference to people.

This page has been set up to make donating simple, it may look odd for this purpose to have a target, but that is part of the JustGiving page make up.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummaryWhat: I am raising funds instead of asking for presents
story:
It would mean a lot to me if you would consider making a donation to WaterAid on my birthday. 

Having access to safe water, toilets and hygiene affects so many aspects of people's lives. Without them health, education, gender inequality, nutrition and prosperity around the globe just aren't possible.

This is a cause I really care about, it would make me really happy on my birthday to raise funds for them!

Thanks so much

Donna 

PS Please Gift Aid your donation if you can!

eventName: "An Expedition to the Summit of Mt Aconcagua (22841feet)
pageSummary: 23 days to the breathless summit of Mt Aconcagua
pageSummaryWhat: 23 days to the breathless summit of Mt Aconcagua
story:
All,

650-million people have to drink dirty-water which threatens their life and so many young children do not see their fifth birthday. 

These are the poorest and most marginalised people in society.

Please help to ensure safe water reaches these people by contributing to my fundraising.

I shall embark on a 23 day expedition of the barren slops of Mt Aconcagua in Argentina and summit at a breathless altitude of 22841 feet.

Thank you kindly

Clint.

This year I have decided to take on the challenge of running a marathon! It is something I never thought that I would attempt but I have been inspired by those around me who have taken on this challenge not only recently but many years ago and conquered it.

There are many worthwhile charities to raise money for and I have chosen wateraid.org. Can you believe that in this day and age there are still people living without clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene? I know i didn't which is why I chose this charity.

I will be very grateful for any donation you are able to make to help me raise money for this worthwhile cause.

eventName: Tabitha is giving up chocolate for January!
pageSummary: Tabitha is giving up chocolate for January because she thinks everyone should have water to drink,
pageSummaryWhat: Tabitha is giving up chocolate for January
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Tabitha’s JustGiving page.

On New Year’s Eve Tabitha watched an advert showing children drinking from puddles. She asked what they were doing so we explained that not everyone has access to clean water. 

“But everyone should have water to drink” she exclaimed indignantly.

I explained I already gave a monthly donation   to Water Aid so she asked if she could too... but as she doesn’t get pocket money this would prove tricky so I suggested she raise some money by doing something or giving something up. 

“Chocolate” she cried.

“Really????” I replied.

To my amazement Tabitha has been chocolate free for three weeks, determined in her mission, so we thought it was about time to ask for a little sponsorship. 

We settled on £36 as this is the equivalent of £3 a month for a year.

Thank you for all donations, we are very grateful for any support.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

pageSummary: NA
story:
In July, I'll be cycling 100 miles in Prudential RideLondon-Surrey 100. Access to clean water is something I take for granted every day, while 844 million people don’t have clean water close to home. Please join me and donate whatever you can - we can do our part to help people in need.

  • £15 can help provide one person with access to
    safe water
  • £24 can help provide a year’s hygiene education
    for one child in Uganda
  • £50 can provide a wheelchair accessible toilet in
    Bangladesh
  • £103 can provide seven hygienic hands-free taps
    to help a hospital in Tanzania

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. eventName: Severn Trent Trust Fund's Charity Challenges
pageSummary: Taking on a series of challenges & fundraisers because every deserves clean water!
pageSummaryWhat: Taking on a series of challenges & fundraisers
story:
The Severn Trent Trust Fund is celebrating it's 20th Anniversary, to celebrate we are undertaking a series of challenges and fundraisers to raise £20,000 for Water Aid. 

So far we have undertaken a variety of challenges including the Great Midlands Fun Run, a Skydive, Tough Sh!t, a Sailing Challenge, a Swimming Challenge and a Bike Challenge. As well as a series of fundraisers. To find out more information about what we have done and what we have coming up please <a href="http://www.sttf.org.uk/about-us/severn-trent-trust-fund-20th-anniversary/">Click here!</a>

We have an upcoming Jailbreak Fundraiser on Tuesday 27th February with the aim of raising £5,000 if you would like to support the Jailbreak you can do so by making a donation here - <a href="http://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/severn-trent-trust-fund-jailbreak">Click here!</a>

If you would like to support the team or keep up to date with how they are getting on, you can do so by checking out the teams charity page here - <a href="http://www.justgiving.com/companyteams/STTFCharityChallenges">Click here!</a>

Or if you would like to make a donation to the team page you can do so by visiting the team page here - <a href="http://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/sttf20">Click here!</a>

pageSummary: Kayaking the Thames from source to sea (nearly!) because Water Aid rock
pageSummaryWhat: Kayaking the Thames from source to sea (nearly!)
story:
Hi friends (and strangers!).

I'm setting out to kayak the Thames from Lechlade to the Thames Barrier at the end of the month. I plan to take about 7 days to do it, which is roughly 22 miles a day.

I've bought a lovely kayak to do it, and I'll be selling it when I arrive in London. I plan to give the money raised from the sale of the Kayak to Water Aid, and a friend suggested I see if anyone else wants to chip in too... so I made this!

You've probably heard of Water Aid before. They have one of those adverts on the TV... in case you haven't, here's a bit from the good people themselves -

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. pageSummary: NA
story:
Ironman Wales is an infamously challenging triathlon, which
is being held on 9 September in Tenby, Pembrokeshire. It’s a gruelling course
that involves:

A two-loop 2.4 mile swim in Carmarthen Bay

A 112 mile cycle through Pembrokeshire Coast
National Park

A 26.2 mile run through Tenby

Five of Welsh Water's colleagues have signed up for this test of
endurance and athleticism, all in the name of charity. This year, they’ll be
running, swimming and cycling their way through tough training programmes ahead
of the big day, and raising funds for WaterAid whilst doing so.

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I am taking on a challenge to trek 100km in 5 days because of the need to help others with clean water supply
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking on a challenge to trek 100km in 5 days
story:
Overall Statement

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. This is the way it should be.

Currently 663million people (10% of the world's population) live without safe water and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. WaterAid aims to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, and hopes to give everyone safe access to water by 2030.

My Personal Statement

In one part of the world, we are talking about the advancement of AI helping human to an easier living but in another part of the world, we are seeing people suffering from limited access to safe water and hygiene. As we are the privileged individual who lives near the better side of the world, we have the responsibility to help the less fortunate in improving their living standard - particularly the younger ones to gain access to safe water and hygiene as well as education to change their life going forward.

It would not make sense to the global population that we forget to help those suffering from situations where we actually have resources to improve their wellbeing. It is thus paramount for us as a community to help humanity move forward - volunteering is important not only because you are helping people in the process, but also providing aspiration to those you are helping, and influence or inspire others around you to do the same. Humanity has survived till now on the basis of people helping eachother and going through difficult situations together, and thus it is important for all of us to volunteer or raise funds to help the less fortunate!



The challenge involves trekking c.100km in about 5 days in Greenland - the world's largest island and one of the least inhabited territories. The entire trek is 160km long, from Kangerlussuaq to Sisimimut, but we will only be doing c.100km of it. There will be almost 24 hours of daylight, temperature of c.20'c in day time and c.5'c at night, and weather should be stable with occasional strong winds and rain. We will be staying in tents and throughout the trip we will be carrying our own equipments and supply while trekking. As part of the briefing note I was told to expect a high degree of mosquitos (never thought of) and water supply will be from lakes and rivers that are safe to drink untreated, as they are primarily fed from snow fields and is frozen for 8 months a year (sound like freeflow of Evian water to me).

As token of appreciation to your donation, I will certainly love to share with you the photos and stories of this once-in-a-life-time trip. Please feel free to mark me for catch up when I am back - or I will be hunting for you!

Last but not least, rest assure that all cost is entirely self funded with all funds raised going to charity. The total fundraising target of the whole Arctic Challenge is GBP500k and it will be sufficient to provide 26,000 people with access to clean water!

pageSummary: NA
story:
Hello! We are a group of 9 graduates who will be holding Race Nights at multiple Thames Water sites between the 4th and 8th June to raise money for WaterAid.

WaterAid work to provide clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene to the world's most marginalised people. With all three, these people can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

So please support this fantastic charity by coming along to one of our Race Nights! There will be food, drink, music, games...and the opportunity to win some great prizes.

To buy a ticket for one of the events, please donate £7.50 per
person. This price includes entry, food & drink, and 3 raffle tickets to
bet with. You can then use these tickets to bet, and the more you win, the more likely you are to win prizes! 

Please specify in your donation what you'd like to buy and which event you'd like to come to.

Events:

  • Monday 4th June: Mogden Sewage Treatment Works 3.30-5.30pm
  • Wednesday 6th June: Clearwater Court 5-7pm

Due to Gambling Restrictions, these events are limited to Thames Water employees only. 

Thank you and we look forward to seeing you there!

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Running the Bristol Half Marathon because everyone has a right to clean drinking water
story:
Access to clean drinking water is a basic human right that every individual should have and unfortunately this isn't the case for far too many people.

Every minute a newborn dies from infection caused by lack of safe water. Diarrhoea caused by dirty water kills a child under 5 every two minutes. 

Education is critical for breaking the cycle of poverty and yet over half of the world's schools lack access to safe water and sanitation facilities. Lack of clean water has serious effects on students' academic performance and attendance rates. The lack of safe water can cause even the best students to lose momentum as they deal with stomach pains and diarrhoea from disease and hunger.

Lack of Water = Lack of Equality

For girls, the situation is especially troublesome. It is typically the responsibility of the women to fetch water thus limiting their access to both education and business opportunities. Think about it: everyday, women and young girls carry more than 40 pounds of dirty water from sources over 4 miles away from their homes. This leaves little time for education which is critical to changing the long term prospects of developing nations.

With the many additional burdens that a lack of clean water brings, education simply becomes less of a priority. This sets up an unfortunate cycle of poverty and inequality as without a proper education, there is little chance of improving one's situation later in life.

I am running the Bristol half marathon in September in order to help change this. Please support me by donating whatever you can. Anything would be greatly appreciated and would help make such a difference to many lives.

Annabelle x

pageSummary: I am trekking 100km in Greenland because clean water should be a right for all
story:
In August 2018, I will go on a 100km trek in the Arctic Circle area of Greenland alongside 99 other HSBC colleagues from around the world. The trip is entirely self-funded, all funds raised will go to WaterAid to support their initiatives in the provision of clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene in areas of need around the world. 

This will be my 2nd fundraising trek for WaterAid after the Gobi Challenge in Mongolia in 2016. We will be camping in the wild and carrying our own gear for the duration of the trek. It will be a tremendous personal challenge and I thank you in advance for your support!

pageSummary: Cycling the lengths of the Rivers Severn & Trent because of the need 4Clean Water & decent toilets in India
pageSummaryWhat: Cycling the lengths of the Rivers Severn & Trent
story:
After an intrepid expedition down the length of the River Trent, and a tough but exciting run in the Peak District, left only for the completion of the 400 miles is a cycle down Britain's longest river: over 200 miles of the River Severn. It may be October: cold, wet, nights drawing in, but Caio and myself will be getting out into the countryside and travelling from the Cambrian Mountains in mid-Wales to the Severn estuary near Bristol.

All this is to raise money for communities in India that don't have clean water or decent toilets, and is going to support WaterAid's work there, as part of this year's WaterAid Winnovators challenge.

Please support us in our goal of raising as much money as possible to better those communities.
title: Rivers Severn & Trent Cycle & Peak District Mountain Run Challenge

pageSummary: I am taking part in Sing for Water West because everyone needs access to clean water
pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in Sing for Water West
story:
Please help me to help others get access to something we in the UK massively take for granted - water. 

After visiting South Africa during one of the worst droughts in many years this summer, their fears of running out of something so basic made me realise how lucky we are here in our green and pleasant land - even in the midst of the sunniest weather!

On Sunday 15th July, I will be performing with **300** others in Bristol's Passenger Shed (AKA Brunel's Old Station). We've been practicing 7 songs for your listening pleasure, so if you can make it, please come along! Its a FREE event! 

Singing as part of a choir has helped me in many ways during the last year, and by performing for you, it is a wonderful way to raise money to help others.

If you can spare a few quid towards helping this wonderful charity establish water sources in remote areas, we would be so grateful. Either via this site or on the day if you can make it!

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
﻿﻿﻿WaterAid enables the worlds poorest people to gain access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene education. These basic human rights underpin health, education and livelihoods and form the first essential step in overcoming poverty.

Since 2016, Thames Water have been working together with WaterAid to transform lives in two towns in Malawi - the worlds poorest country. Currently in Malawi, 10 million people have no safe place to go to the toilet and 1.7million people have no access to safe clean water.

Our team are taking part in the annual one mile raft race organised by Thames Water on the 26th July! Up to 40 themed rafts with battle it out on the river Thames in this annual legendary event. Each team will design, build and decorate their raft and wear fancy dress.

We have chosen 'Usain Boat' as our raft. Usain Bolt is an inspiring and loveable athlete who took the world by storm and due to his achievements and dominance in sprint events is widely considered to be the greatest sprinter of all time. Lets hope our raft can break the record too!

Please dig deep and sponsor us on-line! Also please come and support us on the day!

﻿

﻿

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
In August I am helping to lead a remote expedition within the Arctic Circle in Greenland. We will be trekking across untamed land through multiple terrains with river crossings including tundra and glaciers.   With no access to typical facilities, everyone will be carrying their own equipment and camping gear, sleeping in one of the most remote parts of the world in order to raise money for WaterAid.

Water Aid is the world’s largest NGO focused exclusively on improving access to clean water, sanitation and hygiene for the less privileged. Currently 663 million people, (10% of the world's population), live without safe water and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation.  WaterAid aims to transform the lives of many of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water.
title: Elizabeth's Arctic Challenge Trek Greenland

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Marking 10years without my dad with something good because life is for living and for giving!
pageSummaryWhat: Marking 10years without my dad with something good
story:
﻿﻿Hello!

Thank you for clicking the link, let me share my story with you.

When the clock turned on 2018 and the New Year was brought in I was hit with the fact that it marked 10 whole years without my dad. My dad died young, he was only 49 when he died from Cancer in 2008. It's been a hard 10 years dealing with the loss. So, I want to turn something bad into something good and mark 10 years with a year of positive change - I'm running in his memory...for a whole year!  

My Confirmed Runs (so far) are:

- 24/06/2018: Heaton Park 10K  - Completed
- 08/07/2018: We Love Manchester 10K - Completed
- 18/08/2018: Mix Tape Virtual 5K
- 09/09/2018: Salford 10K
- 23/09/2018: 20 Miles of Summer Virtual
- 14/10/2018: Manchester Half Marathon
- 27/10/2018: Glow In The Park 5K
- 25/11/2018: Wilmslow Festive 10K
- 08/12/2018: Completed It Mate Virtual 10K
- 07/04/2019: Manchester Marathon

I have paid for all these runs myself and have not taken charity spaces. I would really appreciate your donations to WaterAid if you would like to contribute and celebrate my dad's memory.

So why WaterAid?
844 million people living without clean water and 2.3 billion people not having a decent toilet shouldn’t be normal. Thanks to remarkable people donating WaterAid have already made huge progress. But there’s still so much more we need to do. Together, we can reach everyone, everywhere with clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene within a generation – and change normal for good.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page and thanks for the support & love throughout my journey.

Dawn x
title: Running for John (Dad)

story:

With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

We are joining the Bristol Sing for Water event on 15 July 2018 because we want to help create a world where everyone has access to clean water, sanitation and hygiene - basic human rights that most people take for granted. 

The event is taking place in Brunel's astounding Passenger Shed at Bristol Temple Meads. It's cavernous enough to accommodate a giant sized choir. It should sound amazing and we won't have to worry about wind, rain or excessive sun!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: We are...
story:
﻿Thanks for taking the time to look at our Just Giving page.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

The WaterAid Mountain Challenge began over twenty years ago, and is one of WaterAid’s longest-running events.﻿  We will be setting off from Hope Valley College, Hope, Derbyshire and will navigate across the glorious Dark Peak area before descending back through Edale to Hope Valley College a distance of 25 miles.﻿﻿﻿

The 'Mad Dog' team is made up of Mike Jackson, Russ Parker, Ant Ault, Bryce Parker (no relation to Russ - so we have been told), Dan Jackson (Navigator)  and George Webb.

Initial optimism gave way to realism following our practice walk where we completed the first 15 miles of the course Castleton to Edale which took us 6 hours - safe to say it was a lot harder than we thought it would be and if we walk at the same pace it's going to take over 9 hours. So good chance that the team are going to suffer and we might even see grown men cry (specifically Russ) - which has to be worth some sponsorship.

So help this motley outfit and support this great cause by making a donation to our page.

﻿﻿﻿﻿Thanks for taking the time to visit our just giving page
