charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Raising money because I wish all children had clean water to drink
story:
Hello. I'm Aneirin and I'm 9 years old.

After seeing an advert by Water Aid on TV, asking to help children who have to walk miles every day for water and might only find dirty water to drink, I asked my Mum if I could give my pocket money to the charity every week. My Mum said I could and we then talked about different ways people raise money, like sponsored silences, pyjama days at school, car boot sales and my Mum told me about people growing their hair long and getting it cut off to make wigs for people who have to take medicine that makes their hair fall out.

I said, "I want to do that - my hair is really thick and maybe I could even make two wigs!"

So, I have been growing my hair since I was 7 - a ‘Hairathon’ – and now its nearing the length I need, I hope to raise money for Water Aid and I will donate my hair to Little Princess Trust. I need between 7"-12" and just have 7" but that would leave me with no hair, so I will keep going until September and see how long it is then.My mum has set up this JustGiving Page for me collect any donations.

I hope you sponsor me and dig deep to help find clean water for people and to make wigs for poorly girls and boys who lose their hair.

Thank you, Aneirin.
title: Aneirin's Hairathon

pageSummary: I am doing a 100 km trek in Greenland over 8 days because I believe I can bring about change.
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing a 100 km trek in Greenland over 8 days
story:
3Aug18 to 10 Aug18, one hundred colleagues from across HSBC including I will be undertaking a 100 km trek across what is known as the Arctic Circle Trail in Greenland.   We are doing this to support WaterAid who are striving to provide clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene to a number of countries in the developing world.  Having seen first hand the impact of scarcity of water and sanitation facilities, I am committed to supporting this cause along with my colleagues and HSBC who will be make a matching funding for the cause. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

I request all my friends and family to generously support this cause.  Cheers and God Bless!
title: Be the change you want to see in the world - Mahatma Gandhi
attribution: We are a group of 100 people from across HSBC Group offices worldwide who will be embarking on this 100 km trek across the arctic circle in Greenland to support WaterAid.  We believe that this effort will help raise awareness on the importance of water.
pageSummaryWhy: I believe I can bring about change.

pageSummary: I am running 1,000 miles in 2018 for Water Aid because clean water & hygiene are a basic human right
pageSummaryWhat: I am running 1,000 miles in 2018 for Water Aid
story:
This year I’m running 1,000 miles (1,600km) for Water Aid to raise £750 - a bargain at just 75p a mile and twice the distance I ran last year!

Clean water, sanitation and hygiene are a basic human right, not a privilege. Water Aid help millions of people in 28 countries to achieve this right.

I’ll be running multiple 10k’s & Half Marathons, four Ultra Marathons and the Berlin Marathon to help get me to my massive target.

Every £1 you donate will enter you into a raffle to win prizes from a collection worth over £300!

Key Events:
- Multiple 10k’s
- Punk Panther 50k Ultra
- Canalathon 50k Ultra
- Burnsall Trail Half Marathon
- Leeds Half Marathon
- Pieces of 8 Trail Half Marathon
- 2 races & 240km in 8 Days! [Endure 24 Solo & IoW Ultra]
- Yorkshire Three Peaks
- Berlin Marathon

story:
Wardie Parish Church in Edinburgh is raising money for WaterAid until Harvest 2018. When we in the Sunday School primary section heard all about WaterAid and discovered why clean water was so important, a few of us who are around during the summer holidays decided to do something together to raise funds.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

On 5th August, between us we're hoping to build 100 sandcastles on the beach. Any donation, no matter, how small, towards our Great Sandcastle Build is very welcome. Thank you!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I ran the Berlin Marathon 2018 because 844 million people still do not have clean water!!
story:
**UPDATE: On Sunday 16th September 2018 I completed my first ever marathon in 4 hours and 29 minutes. THANK YOU to all my sponsors - we're almost at £2,000 for WaterAid!!**

To get to this point I trained 4-5 x per week with a mix of interval training, long runs, gym sessions and stretching, often before work (and as most of you will know, I'm not a morning person!). I overcame serious pains in my left hip and knees thanks to a month off training (!!!) lots of physio, daily strengthening work and kinesiology tape. I totally changed my diet, switching almost completely to vegetable based carbs and vast amounts of protein. This run really took over my life!

My new target is to raise £2,000 for WaterAid. 

When was the last time you turned on the tap to make a cuppa, flushed the loo, or had a shower? 

It's easy for us to take these things for granted. But did you know that 1 in 9 people on this planet still do not have a clean water source close to home? And that there are more people in this world who own mobile phones, than working toilets?! 

This is a human rights issue. And the more research I do, the more obvious it becomes that this is also about women's empowerment!

1. Toilets:- Across the world 1 in 3 women don't have a toilet at home. These women have to wait for the cover of darkness before they can relieve themselves out in the open. Rape is a very real threat. I can't even imagine how terrifying that must be. 

2. Water collection:- Is seen as women's work. In the developing world women and girls travel an average of 6km every single day to collect dirty water, scooping it from ponds, rivers and boreholes and lugging it home in whatever way they can. That doesn't leave much time or energy for play or education. 

3. Periods:- In some cultures women are entirely excluded while they are menstruating, making them feel dirty and unclean. Over one third of girls in South Asia skip school each month because there are no private toilets to manage their periods.

Thankfully, WaterAid is doing amazing work to turn these issues around: https://youtu.be/J2Vvp8BPjn0

Any money you donate will go a very, very long way. Just £10 could pay for a bag of cement to build the foundations for a toilet. And £37 could pay for a hand pump to support an entire community. 

It would mean the world to me if you could support my run and this fantastic charity :) 

Big love, 

Tash xxxx

pageSummary: Beau is holding a sale plus a go-kart challenge because he wants to pay for some fresh water wells...
pageSummaryWhat: Beau is holding a sale plus a go-kart challenge
story:
***MY PAGE IS STILL ACTIVE FOR FUNDRAISING***

Hello, 

My name is Beau and I am 8 years old. 

I saw an advert on TV with a child who had to walk for 6 hours for dirty water to drink. It made me really sad so I said to my mum and dad that I would like to sell some of my toys, books and clothes so that children don’t have to walk 6 hours and we can fund a well for them.

I am also going to do a Go-Kart challenge on Sunday 8th July when I will ride my Go-Kart around a park in Kent and people can sponsor me per lap or donate. I will probably do 30 mins  and then afterwards, I will ask my friends to come for a picnic and if they want to go on the go-Kart they can pay me £1 a go towards the well!  My mum thinks that's a bit too much but I think it’s worth it.

My target is £360 which is £1 for every minute that the little girl had to walk to get horrible water. Please sponsor me so she doesn't have to do that anymore.

Love Beau

x

From Water Aid...

pageSummary: I am doing lots over the summer raising money because I want to let other children be as lucky as me.
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing lots over the summer raising money
story:
I am very lucky. I have a mummy, a daddy, a brother. I have a house to live in, food to eat, and toys to play with. I also have fresh water, unlike other poor children around the world. I am trying to raise money for these unfortunate people over the summer holidays, doing all sorts of things. I have lots of plans, like...                            

  • Helping people with jobs.      
  • Doing a cycle challenge.
  • Baking cakes.
  • Knitting twiddlymuffs

If anyone has any more ideas, they are welcome to share!!   

Please help me raise money by letting me know if you want a job done or a challenge completed. I will update my webpage whenever I do something for charity, which means you will also be able to see what I've done. Please keep checking back!!

To get things started, Mummy is going to donate £10.00 every time I knit a twiddlymuff before the beginning of next term.

This is why WaterAid is so important:

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Thank you!!

pageSummaryWhat: We are running the London Marathon (eeekkkk!!)
story:
Hey guys, 

Thanks for visiting our Just Giving page! 

For a while we've been talking about wanting to make a difference, however small it may be. We have friends and family taking on huge challenges to raise money for so many worthwhile charities, and we wanted in on the action! As you may be aware, Tom's grandad was one of the people responsible for the founding of WaterAid and so we have decided to take on the great feat of the London Marathon to raise money for this amazing cause. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Any donation you can make to our fundraising effort would be so appreciated and we will make sure we raise a glass (or three) to you once the 26 miles are complete!

Lots of love, 
Tom & Laura xxx

On the 14th September Accenture Technology Strategy will bring a group of 35 Accenture adventurers together for our annual charity challenge. We will be weathering the elements over two days of physical activity, all with the aim of supporting two complimentary charities, Water Aid and Deworm the World.

We aim to cycle 60 miles across Wales, hike through the hillsides over 10 miles and finally paddle from the North of Devon to the South to raise as much as we can for each charity.

pageSummary: I am running the Berlin Marathon 2018 because everyone should have access to clean water
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Berlin Marathon 2018
story:
I recently spent time in refugee camps in Bangladesh and Iraq and have seen firsthand the importance of clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene in order for people to live a dignified and healthy life. WaterAid is running amazing projects around the world to support communities in accessing these things that we take for granted. For every pound donated to WaterAid, 77p go straight to projects. If you would like to know more, read up here: https://www.wateraid.org/uk/our-fundraising-promise

I am running the Berlin Marathon this year to raise awareness and funding for WaterAid's great efforts to continue. Any donation, big or small, in support would be greatly appreciated.

pageSummary: Cycle/Walk/Canoe across Devon from North to South
pageSummaryWhat: Cycle/Walk/Canoe across Devon from North to South
story:
Every now and again its good to do something a little challenging and for a good cause.

On the 14/15th September, myself and 40 other fine colleagues will be Cycling, Walking, and Canoeing 80miles from North to South Devon across the beautiful but challenging moorland.

This year as a group we have selected Water Aid as a Charity - the rational is simple  and below. 

In addition.  Some of you will be aware of the challenges faced by my oldest friend and his family. He has received excellent support from Clik Sargent (and other charities) while his 6 month baby boy undergoes chemo for LCH. I want to say thank you to them helping one of my dearest friends. I will match 25% of whatever I raise here and donate to this marvellous charity.  Dig deep people - make me pay.

In case you are not aware of the brilliant mission of Water Aid its pretty simple, and very compelling.  Especially when you consider what we take for granted.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

P.s All donations will go to charity.

story:
From 14th-15th September I will be cycling, walking, and canoeing over 80 miles across Devon from Barnstaple to Dartmouth together with my colleagues to raise money for WaterAid and help provide those in need the most basic of human needs - clean water.


I will be covering all my travel, accommodation, and equipment costs so that 100% of your contribution will be donated to WaterAid.


Please help me achieve this by donating to my page.


Thank you!


Stuart

pageSummary: Severn Trent Mountain Challenge for Water Aid because it's an event that we love and a fantastic cause!
pageSummaryWhat: Severn Trent Mountain Challenge for Water Aid
story:
This years Severn Trent Mountain Challenge is a 25 mile hike up hill and down dale in the Derbyshire peaks. Oracle's team include Sam Eden, Gary Wood, John Bald and Jon Burton. Armed with youthful exuberance, healthy bodies and minds we are up for the challenge. 

Sam Eden is a hardcore marathon running enthusiast and has lowered himself to walk with the rest of us. 3rd time at the 7 Trent MC he is almost a veteran...Sparta!!

Gary Wood has been walking recreationally for around 26 years now and is here to recognise walking as a challenge. He has even broken in his new boots playing lacrosse and tennis this week and his youthful naivety and exuberance will soon be crushed having to carry the older members of the team around the course. 

John Bald is here...in body...if not spirit..yet. After at least one training walk he is in the peak of physical condition and sees this stroll in the park as a bronzing exercise.

Jon Burton, Oracle's MD, has taken part in this event many times over the last 20 years and strongly believes in Water Aid's cause and objectives. The event has proven to be a real challenge over the years but carrying a recently ruptured calf...this year's event could be the toughest yet.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. I appreciate any donation you can make. Don't forget to gift aid! Thanks,

Jon

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: NA
story:
Did you know that collectively, women and girls spend 200 million hours fetching water every day? That’s according to a Unicef study, which also described the figure as a “colossal waste of their valuable time.”

When water is not piped to the home the burden of fetching it falls disproportionately on women and children, especially girls. The opportunity costs of collecting water are high, with far reaching effects. For both boys and girls, water collection can take time away from their education and sometimes even prevent them attending school altogether.

The UK-based charity WaterAid has teams in 34 countries across the world who work with partners to transform millions of lives every year by improving access to clean water, toilets and hygiene. 

We’re supporting WaterAid by undertaking our own walk, coast-to-coast across England, following the impressive Hadrian’s Wall built in AD122.  At 135km (or 84 miles) that’s a long way for little legs, but with your help, we hope our efforts will make just that little bit of a difference to children and families less fortunate than us. 

Thank you,

Ruby Creen (aged 7)
title: Ruby Walks Hadrian's Wall-2018

pageSummary: 105mile Triathlon from Coast to Coast (Scotland) because clean water is the most basic essential..
story:
We've had a brief Hiatus since conquering Snowdon in 2015, but we're back for more!! 

On the 8th September 2018 Seb and myself are attempting a 105 mile Coast to Coast crossing of Scotland. This entails 21 miles of running, 83 miles of cycling (on and off-road) and 2 miles of kayaking... All at the mercy of the Scottish elements, into the prevailing wing and with 2 miles of elevation to contend with..!! Its going to be a long day..

We'd love your support and would encourage and gratefully welcome financial gifts to a superb charity. Water Aid aims to ensure clean and healthy drinking water to be made available for all, please help if you can..

Seb and Hugh

pageSummary: I am doing a 24 hour fast because I want people to have clean water
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing a 24 hour fast
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hi, my name is Becky and I learned about Water Aid in school. The world provides plenty of water for everyone, but some people live in places where water is hard to find and dirty. We have plenty and we don’t understand the value of it as a result, we waste it. 3 children die per minute because of dirty water containing worms, parasites and mud, that’s 180 in the last hour. I would want someone to do something about it if it were me and so would you, that’s what Water Aid are doing. Please sponsor me a few pounds and you can help save lives. Every penny counts. Thank you.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Sing for Water at Totally Thames
pageSummary: NA
story: Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to stay alive, go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be. Tragically, it is not normal in a huge part of our world. Mothers have to take themselves, often substantial distances to give birth, collecting and carrying water for their own birthing. Those who manage the work of reaching a clinic, carrying their water, may face giving birth on soiled sheets, the use of unwashed instruments and generally far from hygeinic conditions.  After birth, mothers must choose either to let babies die of dehydration u nder hot sun, or risk babies' lives by hydrating them with dirty water. Children collect water for the family, walking several miles before school, then attending school with no bathrooms, a serious deterrent to school attendance for older children in particular. And so.... Water Aid is present, transforming areas one by one, by the building of water systems, building sanitary provision and teaching hygiene, to establish durable facilities and transform lives for millions, one step at a time. Please donate as much as you are able, to speed Water Aid's progress through regions of the world so desperately in need of its gifts. Thank you.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: Fundraising for Water Aid
story:
Together with my colleagues, I will cycle 60 miles across the Devon countryside, hike 10 miles through hills, and end in a dragon boat from North Devon to South.

The charity I have chosen to support this year is WaterAid because while water is the most important thing for humans' survival and health, there are still many places in the world where it is a luxury. 

C﻿lean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. This affects especially children. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier and get a chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive.

Help me raise some money for this worthy cause!

Thanks!

Angela

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I'm doing the London 2019 Marathon because I want to raise money for water
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

At a young age I wanted to be able to help the people by improving the infrastructure around us, easing transportation, providing power to families homes and ensuring clean water would be only steps away. Following this path lead me to study for several years eventually become a civil engineer that hopefully helps make the world a better place.

Running for WaterAid was the next best thing to do in order to raise awareness and support people who are less fortunate then us. The team at WaterAid has been extremely supportive in helping with the gruelling race coming up. 

 Thank you for your support.

pageSummary: London landmarks half marathon because I am bored and want to help those less fortunate
story: As you may know, I do not like running but I like racing people over different courses.  What I should be doing is at least helping those less fortunate than ourselves in the process and WaterAid seem to be the best fit for a charity that I want to help.  I'm not going to give you a story about how vital water is and how fortunate we are to have it on tap, you should all know that.  What I want from you is your money basically so that it can help in a small way get clean water, decent toilets, and good hygiene to people where it doesn't come easy, if at all.  Your donations will help with this and maybe raise a smile on my face.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
pageSummary: I’m running the Royal Parks half marathon because clean water & good loos should be available to all
pageSummaryWhat: I’m running the Royal Parks half marathon
story:
I have supported WaterAid ever since my early 20s when I lived in Nepal for a year and saw first hand the difference clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene made to communities and their ability to thrive.  It’s also the main charity supported by the Environment Agency so it seems right to be running for WaterAid to mark 22yrs in the Environment Agency before I leave to join the Cabinet Office. 

My daughter Emma is also running with me and it’s her first half marathon.  She wants to go into the Navy as a helicopter pilot and is raising money for Blesma which helps military personnel who have lost limbs. She is targeting her fundraising on our family and friends so I’m only asking work colleagues, but of course if Blesma is close to your heart then please sponsor her instead! Her page is https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/emma-baptiste1

As good things often come in threes, I will also match whatever is donated on this site for Alzheimer’s Society as my lovely Dad suffers from this horrid disease.
